examples.en: Please direct your questions to the presidium at the front of the hall.
examples.zh: 请把问题提给大厅前方的大会主席团。

examples.en: The presidium announced the voting procedure.
examples.zh: 大会主席团宣布了投票程序。

extraExplanation: “presidium”常出现在政治与历史语境中，尤其与苏联（USSR）及其政治制度相关。例如“Presidium of the Supreme Soviet”（苏联最高苏维埃主席团）曾在形式上承担国家元首的部分职能。
词源来自拉丁语 *praesidere*（意为“主持、监管”）。英语里它带有较强的“正式、体制化”色彩；日常公司场景更常说 *board*, *executive committee*, *leadership* 等。

summary.en: Presley is a surname, most famously associated with Elvis Presley, the American singer known as the “King of Rock and Roll.”
summary.zh: Presley 是一个姓氏；最著名的相关人物是美国歌手埃尔维斯·普雷斯利，被称为“摇滚之王”。

definition.en: A family name (surname).
definition.zh: 姓氏；家族姓。

examples.en: My friend’s last name is Presley.
examples.zh: 我朋友的姓是 Pres ley（普雷斯利）。

examples.en: The report was written by Dr. Presley.
examples.zh: 这份报告是 Presley 博士写的。

definition.en: Most commonly, it refers to Elvis Presley (1935–1977), a hugely influential American singer and actor often called “the King of Rock and Roll.”
definition.zh: 最常见的指代是埃尔维斯·普雷斯利（Elvis Presley，1935–1977），极具影响力的美国歌手、演员，常被称为“摇滚之王”。

examples.en: Elvis Presley recorded many classic songs in the 1950s and 1960s.
examples.zh: 埃尔维斯·普雷斯利在 20 世纪五六十年代录制了许多经典歌曲。

examples.en: That performance reminded me of Presley’s early rock-and-roll style.
examples.zh: 那场表演让我想起普雷斯利早期的摇滚风格。

synonyms: the King of Rock and Roll
extraExplanation: “Presley”作为专有名词，通常首字母大写。若语境没有给出名（first name），英语读者往往会联想到 Elvis Presley。
文化上，Elvis Presley 常被视为把非裔美国人的节奏布鲁斯（R&B）与乡村音乐等元素带入主流流行文化的重要人物；在美国流行文化、电影与音乐史中常被提及。

summary.en: Press means to push with steady force; it can also mean to persuade/pressure, to iron clothes, or (as a noun) the news media or a pressing machine.
summary.zh: Press 的核心是“按压/施压”：可指按按钮、逼问/催促、熨烫；作名词可指媒体或压制机器。

definition.en: to push something with steady force (often a button, switch, or surface)
definition.zh: 用稳定的力量按/压某物（常指按钮、开关或表面）

examples.en: Press the button to start the machine.
examples.zh: 按下按钮来启动机器。

examples.en: She pressed her hand against the window.
examples.zh: 她把手按在窗户上。

definition.en: to try hard to persuade someone or strongly ask for something
definition.zh: 竭力劝说；强烈要求/催促

examples.en: The lawyer pressed the witness for a clear answer.
examples.zh: 律师逼问证人给出明确答复。

examples.en: I didn’t want to go, but my friends kept pressing me.
examples.zh: 我不想去，但朋友一直催我/劝我。

definition.en: to iron clothes by using heat and pressure
definition.zh: 熨烫（用加热和压力把衣服熨平）

examples.en: He pressed his shirt before the interview.
examples.zh: 面试前他把衬衫熨了一下。

definition.en: newspapers, TV, and online news organizations; the media
definition.zh: 新闻界；媒体（报纸、电视和网络新闻机构等）

examples.en: The press asked the mayor questions after the speech.
examples.zh: 演讲后媒体向市长提问。

examples.en: The story quickly spread in the press.
examples.zh: 这条新闻很快在媒体上传开。

definition.en: a machine or tool that presses something (for example, to shape it or remove liquid)
definition.zh: 压机；榨汁机；压制工具（用于成形或挤出液体等）

examples.en: They used a press to shape the metal parts.
examples.zh: 他们用压机把金属零件压制成形。

examples.en: An olive press is used to extract oil from olives.
examples.zh: 橄榄压榨机用来从橄榄中榨出油。

extraExplanation: “Press”作动词时的核心意象是“施加持续的压力”。因此它既可以是物理上的“按压”（press a button），也可以引申为心理/话语上的“施压、逼问”（press for details）。
常见搭配：press for（强烈要求/追问）; press on（继续前进/坚持下去）; press charges（提起诉讼/控告）; press conference（新闻发布会）。
文学与文化中，“the press”常象征公共舆论与监督力量；在表达上可中性（the press reported...），也可能带批评意味（blame the press）。

summary.en: “Pressare” is an Italian verb meaning “to press” (literally) or “to put pressure on/urge” (figuratively).
summary.zh: “pressare”是意大利语动词，字面意思是“按/压”，引申义是“施压/催促”。

definition.en: (Italian) to press; to squeeze or push something firmly.
definition.zh: （意大利语）按压；挤压；用力推压某物。

examples.en: In Italian, “pressare” means “to press,” like pressing a button.
examples.zh: 在意大利语里，“pressare”意思是“按”，比如按按钮。

examples.en: He told me to “pressare” the dough gently with my hands.
examples.zh: 他让我用手轻轻按压面团。

definition.en: (Italian, figurative) to put pressure on someone; to urge or push someone to act.
definition.zh: （意大利语，引申义）给某人施压；催促某人行动。

examples.en: They tried to “pressare” him to make a quick decision.
examples.zh: 他们试图催他尽快做决定。

examples.en: Don’t “pressare” your friend—give them time.
examples.zh: 别催你的朋友——给他们一点时间。

extraExplanation: “pressare”是意大利语动词，不是常见英语单词。它来自拉丁语词根，与英语的 press（按、压）同源，所以含义很接近。
如果你想表达英语里的对应说法，常用动词是 press（按压）、squeeze（挤压）、push（推），引申“施压”可用 pressure（作动词：to pressure someone）或 urge（催促）。

summary.en: Pressboard is a stiff, thick paperboard made by pressing paper fibers; commonly used for folders, covers, and sometimes insulation.
summary.zh: Pressboard 指由纸纤维压制成的坚硬厚纸板，常用于文件夹、封面，有时也用于绝缘材料。

definition.en: A stiff, thick paperboard made by pressing layers of paper pulp together; used for covers, folders, packaging, and as an insulating material.
definition.zh: 压制纸板；由纸浆层压并压制成的坚硬厚纸板，常用于封面、文件夹、包装，也可作绝缘材料。

examples.en: The report was bound with a pressboard cover to protect it.
examples.zh: 这份报告用压制纸板封面装订，以保护内容。

examples.en: We stored the certificates in pressboard folders.
examples.zh: 我们把证书放在压制纸板文件夹里保存。

examples.en: Some electrical parts use pressboard as insulation.
examples.zh: 一些电气部件会用压制纸板作绝缘材料。

extraExplanation: “pressboard”是复合词：press（压）+ board（板）。它通常指比普通纸张更厚更硬的纸板，但一般不如“cardboard（瓦楞纸板/硬纸板）”那样用于大箱子；更常见于文具（文件夹、封面）或工业绝缘。
在办公用品里你可能会看到“pressboard folder / pressboard report cover”等搭配；在电气领域也常出现“pressboard insulation（压制纸板绝缘）”。

summary.en: “Pressed” can mean (1) pushed/squeezed (past of press), (2) stressed or short of time, or (3) ironed flat (clothes).
summary.zh: “Pressed”常见意思有三种：（1）按压（press 的过去式/过去分词）；（2）有压力、时间紧；（3）（衣物）熨平、整洁。

definition.en: Past tense and past participle of “press”: to push or squeeze something with steady force.
definition.zh: “press”的过去式和过去分词：用持续的力量按、压或挤某物。

examples.en: She pressed the button to start the machine.
examples.zh: 她按下按钮来启动机器。

examples.en: He pressed his hands against the glass.
examples.zh: 他把手按在玻璃上。

definition.en: Under pressure; feeling stressed or having too little time.
definition.zh: 处于压力之下；感到紧张、时间不够用的。

examples.en: I’m really pressed for time today.
examples.zh: 我今天时间真的很紧。

examples.en: They’re pressed to meet the deadline.
examples.zh: 他们为了赶截止日期压力很大。

definition.en: Flattened or made smooth by ironing; also used for clothing that looks neat after ironing.
definition.zh: （衣物）被熨平的；（看起来）熨得很整齐的。

examples.en: He wore a freshly pressed shirt.
examples.zh: 他穿了一件刚熨好的衬衫。

extraExplanation: 常见搭配：pressed for time（时间紧）、pressed for money（手头紧）、pressed to do sth.（被迫/不得不做某事，或在压力下努力做某事）。语气通常表示“资源不够用”。
“pressed”作为“熨平的”多用于服装场景，搭配如 freshly pressed / well-pressed，强调整洁正式的感觉。

summary.en: “Presser” most commonly means a person who presses/irons clothes; it can also mean a pressing machine, or a sports player who applies pressure to opponents.
summary.zh: “Presser”最常指熨烫衣物的工作人员；也可指压制/压榨设备，或体育比赛中负责施压逼抢的球员。

definition.en: A person whose job is to press (iron) clothes, especially professionally (e.g., in a laundry or tailor shop).
definition.zh: 熨烫工；（尤指在洗衣店或裁缝店）专门负责熨烫衣物的人。

examples.en: The presser removed the wrinkles from my suit before the interview.
examples.zh: 面试前，熨烫工把我西装上的褶皱都熨平了。

examples.en: Our hotel has an in-house presser for uniforms.
examples.zh: 我们酒店有专门负责熨烫制服的熨烫工。

definition.en: A tool or machine that presses something into shape or squeezes it, especially in food processing or manufacturing.
definition.zh: 压榨机；压制器；（尤指食品加工或制造业中的）压制设备。

examples.en: They use an olive presser to extract the oil.
examples.zh: 他们用橄榄压榨机来榨油。

examples.en: The workshop bought a new presser for making metal parts.
examples.zh: 车间买了一台新的压制设备来生产金属零件。

definition.en: In sports, a player who applies pressure to the opponent (for example, by pressing high up the field in soccer).
definition.zh: （体育）施压的球员；（如足球中）积极逼抢的队员。

examples.en: Their fastest presser forced a mistake near the goal.
examples.zh: 他们最快的逼抢球员在门前附近逼出了对方失误。

examples.en: We need more pressers to win the ball back quickly.
examples.zh: 我们需要更多积极逼抢的球员，才能更快把球抢回来。

extraExplanation: “Presser”来自动词 press（按压、施压、熨烫）。在美式英语里，衣物相关的“presser”常见于洗衣店/干洗店语境；而体育语境中的“presser”更常见于足球战术讨论（high press、pressing）。注意不要与“press”=媒体（the press）混淆。

summary.en: “Presses” most often means (1) he/she/it **presses** = pushes or applies pressure, or (2) **presses** = machines that press/print; sometimes it can refer to multiple media outlets.
summary.zh: “presses”最常见含义是（1）动词：他/她/它按/压；（2）名词复数：压机/印刷机等；有时也可指多家媒体。

definition.en: third-person singular of **press**: to push something firmly, especially to operate a button or to apply force/pressure.
definition.zh: **press** 的第三人称单数：用力按/压（尤其是按按钮、施加压力）。

examples.en: He presses the button to start the machine.
examples.zh: 他按下按钮来启动机器。

examples.en: The nurse presses on the wound to stop the bleeding.
examples.zh: 护士按住伤口以止血。

definition.en: plural of **press** (machine/tool): machines used to shape materials or print; also devices that squeeze something to remove liquid.
definition.zh: **press** 的复数（机器/工具）：用于压制成形或印刷的机器；也可指榨汁、压榨用的装置。

examples.en: The factory has two large presses for making metal parts.
examples.zh: 这家工厂有两台大型冲压机来制造金属零件。

examples.en: Wine presses were used to crush grapes.
examples.zh: 压榨机被用来压碎葡萄。

definition.en: plural of **press** (media): newspapers and journalists as a group (often written as **the press**).
definition.zh: **press** 的复数（媒体）：报刊与记者群体（常写作 **the press**，意为“新闻界/媒体”）。

examples.en: The actor avoided the presses and entered through a side door.
examples.zh: 这位演员躲开了媒体记者，从侧门进入。

examples.en: The minister spoke to the press after the meeting.
examples.zh: 部长在会议后对媒体发表讲话。

extraExplanation: “the press”在英语里常作集合名词，泛指新闻界/媒体，不一定需要用复数；但在某些语境里也会看到“presses”表示“多家媒体/多路记者”。

summary.en: “Pressing” most often means urgent and needing immediate attention; it can also be the -ing form of “press,” meaning to push/squeeze or to pressure someone.
summary.zh: “Pressing”最常见表示“紧迫的、亟需处理的”；也可以是动词press的现在分词，表示“按压/熨烫”或“催促、施压”。

definition.en: needing attention immediately; urgent and important
definition.zh: 紧迫的；亟需立刻处理的

examples.en: Climate change is a pressing issue for many communities.
examples.zh: 气候变化对许多社区来说是一个紧迫的问题。

examples.en: I have a pressing deadline, so I can’t stay long.
examples.zh: 我有个很紧迫的截止日期，所以不能久留。

definition.en: currently pushing or touching something with steady force; squeezing/ironing by applying pressure
definition.zh: 正在按压/挤压；（用压力）熨烫、压平

examples.en: She was pressing the button when the screen lit up.
examples.zh: 她按下按钮时，屏幕亮了。

examples.en: He’s pressing his shirt before the interview.
examples.zh: 他在面试前熨烫衬衫。

definition.en: strongly requesting or urging someone to do something; putting pressure on someone
definition.zh: 强烈要求/催促；向某人施压

examples.en: They are pressing the manager for an answer.
examples.zh: 他们在催经理给出答复。

examples.en: Don’t keep pressing me—I already said no.
examples.zh: 别一直逼我——我已经说不行了。

extraExplanation: “Pressing”最常见作形容词，常搭配：pressing issue/question/matter/need（紧迫的问题/事项/需求）。语气比“important”更强调“时间紧、必须尽快处理”。
动词press的相关名词press既可以指“新闻媒体/出版社”，也可以指“按压机器（如印刷机、榨汁机）”；但这些含义与“pressing（紧迫的）”并不完全相同，注意区分。

summary.en: “Pression” is an uncommon noun meaning “pressure” or the act/effect of pressing; in modern English, “pressure” is usually preferred.
summary.zh: “Pression”是一个不常用的名词，表示“压力”或“按压的动作/效果”；现代英语通常更常用“pressure”。

definition.en: (Uncommon) pressure; the act of pressing or the force produced by pressing.
definition.zh: （不常用）压力；按压的动作或由按压产生的力量。

examples.en: In older technical writing, “pression” sometimes appears where modern English would use “pressure.”
examples.zh: 在较早的技术写作中，“pression”有时会出现在现代英语更常用“pressure”的位置。

examples.en: The device measures the pression inside the chamber.
examples.zh: 该装置测量腔室内的压力。

definition.en: (Rare, stylistic) an impression or effect made by pressing; a “pressing-in” feeling.
definition.zh: （罕见/文体用法）由按压造成的印痕或影响；一种“被压入”的感觉。

examples.en: The wet clay kept the pression of the seal.
examples.zh: 湿黏土保留了印章的压痕。

examples.en: He felt a strange pression on his chest and stopped to breathe.
examples.zh: 他感到胸口有种奇怪的压迫感，便停下来呼吸。

extraExplanation: “pression”在现代日常英语中非常少见，更常见的是“pressure（压力）”。你更可能在法语语境（法语里pression=压力）或较旧的科技/工程文本中看到它。
词形上，-pression 常作为构词成分出现在更常用的词里：expression（表达/表情）、impression（印象）、depression（抑郁/凹陷）、compression（压缩）等。学习时可把它与“press（按、压）”的核心含义联系起来。

summary.en: Pressure means physical force pushing on something, mental stress from demands, or the act of forcing/persuading someone.
summary.zh: pressure 可指物理压力（如气压、血压），也可指心理压力，或指对他人施压/逼迫。

definition.en: the force of something pushing on a surface, especially air or liquid pressing on something
definition.zh: 压力；（尤指）气体或液体对某物表面施加的挤压作用

examples.en: The doctor checked my blood pressure.
examples.zh: 医生测了我的血压。

examples.en: Tire pressure drops in cold weather.
examples.zh: 天气冷时，轮胎气压会下降。

definition.en: stress or worry caused by demands, responsibilities, or difficult situations
definition.zh: （精神/心理）压力；（因要求、责任或困境带来的）紧张与焦虑

examples.en: She’s under a lot of pressure at work.
examples.zh: 她工作压力很大。

examples.en: Peer pressure can influence teenagers’ choices.
examples.zh: 同伴压力会影响青少年的选择。

definition.en: to try to persuade or force someone to do something, often unfairly
definition.zh: 施压；逼迫；强迫（某人做某事，常带有不公平或不情愿的意味）

examples.en: Don’t let anyone pressure you into signing a contract.
examples.zh: 不要让任何人逼你签合同。

examples.en: He felt pressured to agree.
examples.zh: 他感到被迫同意。

extraExplanation: “pressure”既可指物理上的“压强/气压/水压”，也常用来指心理上的“压力”。在日常英语里，under pressure（在压力之下）和pressure someone into doing something（逼某人做某事）非常常见。
词源来自拉丁语 pressare（按压、挤压），所以它的核心意象是“向下按/挤”的力量；这种意象也延伸到“对人施压”的比喻用法。

summary.en: “Pressured” means feeling pushed or under stress, often by time or other people; it can also mean “under increased pressure” in technical contexts.
summary.zh: “pressured”指感到被催促、被施压或压力很大；在技术语境中也可指“被加压的/压力升高的”。

definition.en: Feeling stress, urgency, or being pushed to act by demands, time limits, or other people.
definition.zh: 感到有压力的；被催促的；因要求或时间限制而感到紧迫的。

examples.en: I’ve been really pressured at work this week, so I’m tired.
examples.zh: 我这周工作压力很大，所以很累。

examples.en: Students often feel pressured to get good grades.
examples.zh: 学生常常感到必须拿到好成绩的压力。

examples.en: Don’t let anyone make you feel pressured to decide today.
examples.zh: 不要让任何人逼你今天就做决定。

definition.en: Made to have higher pressure (often in science/engineering contexts), as in air or a container.
definition.zh: （常用于科学/工程语境）被加压的；压力升高的（如空气或容器）。

examples.en: The tank holds pressured gas.
examples.zh: 这个罐子装着加压气体。

examples.en: Pressured air can power some tools.
examples.zh: 加压空气可以驱动一些工具。

extraExplanation: “pressured”常来自短语 **feel pressured (to do something)**（感到被迫/被催促做某事）或 **be pressured into doing something**（被逼着去做某事）。语气上，**pressured**偏“外界施压”，而 **stressed**更常指“整体压力大、焦虑”。
拼写与构词：来自动词 **pressure**（施压/压力），加上过去分词形式表示“处于被施压的状态”。

summary.en: Pressurize means to raise the pressure inside something (common in aviation/engineering) or, figuratively, to put pressure on people or a situation.
summary.zh: Pressurize 指给某物增压（常见于航空/工程），也可引申为对人或局势施压、让其更紧迫。

definition.en: to increase the air or gas pressure inside something; to fill something with pressurized air or gas
definition.zh: 给某物增压；向某物充入加压空气或气体

examples.en: The plane’s cabin is pressurized so passengers can breathe comfortably at high altitudes.
examples.zh: 飞机客舱会被增压，这样乘客在高空也能舒适呼吸。

examples.en: Before the dive, the crew pressurized the tank with oxygen.
examples.zh: 下潜前，工作人员用氧气给气瓶增压。

definition.en: to make a situation feel urgent or stressful, often by applying pressure to people or decisions
definition.zh: （使局势）紧迫化；（常指对人或决策）施压使其感到有压力

examples.en: The tight deadline pressurized the whole team.
examples.zh: 紧迫的截止日期让整个团队压力倍增。

examples.en: Don’t pressurize her—give her time to decide.
examples.zh: 别给她施压，让她有时间做决定。

extraExplanation: “pressurize”常用于工程/航空语境，搭配如：pressurize the cabin（给客舱增压）、pressurize a system/pipe/tank（给系统/管道/储罐增压）。
比喻义（“施压、让人感到压力”）在口语里也很常见，但正式写作中有时会用 pressure 或 put pressure on 来表达更自然：Don’t pressure her. / Don’t put pressure on her.

summary.en: Pressus is a Latin-derived term meaning “pressed/compressed,” seen mainly in older scientific or medical phrases.
summary.zh: Pressus 源自拉丁语，意为“被压紧/被压缩”，主要见于较旧的科学或医学短语中。

definition.en: (Latin-derived; used mainly in scientific or medical writing) “pressed,” “compressed,” or “compacted.”
definition.zh: （源自拉丁语；多用于科学或医学语境）“被压紧的 / 被压扁的 / 压缩的、紧密的”。

examples.en: In a few older descriptions, a structure may be labeled pressus to mean it looks flattened or tightly packed.
examples.zh: 在一些较旧的描述里，某个结构可能会被标为 pressus，表示它看起来被压扁或很紧密。

examples.en: The term is sometimes used in Latin-style labels in taxonomy or anatomy notes.
examples.zh: 这个词有时会出现在分类学或解剖笔记中的拉丁式标注里。

definition.en: (Medicine, in phrases) describing a pulse that feels weak or hard to detect due to low force.
definition.zh: （医学，多见于短语中）形容脉搏力量很弱、触诊不明显。

examples.en: The clinician noted a “pulsus pressus,” meaning the pulse was very faint.
examples.zh: 临床记录写了“pulsus pressus”，意思是脉搏非常微弱。

extraExplanation: pressus 本身不是现代英语里的常用词，更像是拉丁语分词/形容词（意为“被按压的、被压紧的”），偶尔保留在旧式医学术语或学术拉丁标注中。
现代英语中更常用的对应词是 pressed, compressed, compact(ed), flattened 等；如果你是在某篇论文、标本描述或病历里看到它，通常需要结合上下文判断它是在“形态被压扁/紧密”还是“脉搏微弱”等专业含义。

summary.en: Prestige means the high respect and strong reputation someone or something has, often connected to social status and public admiration.
summary.zh: Prestige 指因声誉与社会认可而获得的高度尊敬与名望，常与地位、体面和公众仰慕有关。

definition.en: high respect and admiration that a person, job, institution, or brand receives; a strong, widely recognized good reputation
definition.zh: 声望；威信；名望（因成就、地位或口碑而受到广泛尊敬与仰慕）

examples.en: The university has international prestige for its research.
examples.zh: 这所大学因其研究成果而享有国际声望。

examples.en: She chose the job for the prestige, not the salary.
examples.zh: 她选择这份工作是因为它有面子/声望，而不是因为薪水。

definition.en: social status or influence that comes from being respected or seen as important
definition.zh: （由社会认可带来的）地位与影响力；体面

examples.en: In some families, prestige matters more than personal happiness.
examples.zh: 在一些家庭里，面子与地位比个人幸福更重要。

examples.en: He gained prestige after winning the national award.
examples.zh: 他获得国家级奖项后，声望大增。

extraExplanation: “Prestige”常指“被别人认可的尊敬与名声”，通常带有“外界评价/社会观感”的意味；如果想强调“内在的道德品质带来的尊敬”，英语里也常用“honor”或“integrity”。
常见搭配：gain/earn prestige（赢得声望）、lose prestige（失去声望）、prestige brand/university/job（有名望的品牌/大学/工作）。
文学与文化用法中，“prestige”有时会暗示“表面光鲜的地位象征”，因此在批评语境里可能带一点讽刺色彩。

summary.en: “Prestigious” describes something highly respected and admired, with high status.
summary.zh: “prestigious”指“有声望的、受尊敬的、地位很高的”。

definition.en: Respected and admired by many people; having high status because of success, quality, or importance.
definition.zh: 享有声望的；受人尊敬的；有很高地位的（因成就、质量或重要性而受认可）

examples.en: She got a job at a prestigious law firm in New York.
examples.zh: 她在纽约一家享有盛誉的律师事务所找到了工作。

examples.en: Winning that prestigious award changed his career.
examples.zh: 赢得那个有声望的奖项改变了他的职业生涯。

examples.en: They chose a prestigious university for its research programs.
examples.zh: 他们选择了一所知名大学，因为它的科研项目很强。

extraExplanation:
“prestigious”常用来形容机构（university, school, company）、奖项（award, prize）、职位（position）、活动（festival）等带来社会认可与地位的事物。它强调“社会评价高”，不一定等同于“真的最好”。

搭配很常见：prestigious university/school, prestigious award/prize, prestigious journal, prestigious position, prestigious conference。

近义词细微差别：
- famous = 出名（不一定受尊敬）
- respected = 受尊敬（不一定“名气大”）
- elite = 精英的/顶尖圈层的（带“群体/阶层”色彩）

词源提示：与“prestige（声望）”同源，来自拉丁语，原意与“幻象/魔法”相关，后来引申为“影响力/威望”。

summary.en: “Presumably” means “as far as we can guess from what we know,” but it’s not 100% certain.
summary.zh: “presumably”表示“根据已知情况推断，大概/想必如此”，但并非完全确定。

definition.en: used to say that something is believed to be true based on what is known, though it is not completely certain
definition.zh: 据推测；大概；想必（根据已知信息认为可能为真，但不完全确定）

examples.en: She is presumably at home by now.
examples.zh: 她现在想必已经到家了。

examples.en: The meeting will presumably start at 10, unless there’s a delay.
examples.zh: 会议大概十点开始，除非有延误。

examples.en: He didn’t call, presumably because he was busy.
examples.zh: 他没打电话，想必是因为忙。

extraExplanation: “presumably”语气比“probably”更偏向“根据现有线索/常识推断”，常用于写作或正式表达；但它仍然保留“不确定”的余地。
放在句首时常用来引出推断（Presumably, ...）；放在句中/句末则更自然地修饰整句（... presumably ...）。

summary.en: Presume means to suppose something is true without full proof, or (often negatively) to take too much for granted and act too boldly.
summary.zh: Presume 表示“推测/假定（缺乏充分证据）”，也可表示（常带贬义）“冒昧、自作主张、得寸进尺”。

definition.en: to believe something is true without full proof; to suppose
definition.zh: 在没有充分证据时认为某事为真；推测、假定

examples.en: I presume you’re tired after the long flight.
examples.zh: 我猜想你坐了长途飞机后一定很累。

examples.en: We presumed the store was closed because the lights were off.
examples.zh: 因为灯都关着，我们推测那家店已经关门了。

definition.en: to act as if something is true or allowed, often in a way that seems rude or too confident
definition.zh: 擅自认为（某事）理所当然或被允许，常带有唐突、自以为是的感觉

examples.en: Don’t presume to tell me how to do my job.
examples.zh: 别自以为是地教我怎么做我的工作。

examples.en: He presumed on their kindness and asked for another favor.
examples.zh: 他仗着他们的好心，又开口求了一个忙。

extraExplanation: “presume”常见于较正式的语境。它比“guess”更像“基于常识或已有信息的推断”，但仍可能不确定。
语气差异：I presume…（我推测/想必…）通常比较礼貌；但“presume to do”或“presume on/upon…”则常带贬义，表示“冒昧、僭越、得寸进尺”。
常见搭配：presume that + 从句；presume (someone/something) to be…；presume to do…；presume on/upon…

summary.en: Presumed means assumed or generally believed to be true based on available information, but not proven.
summary.zh: Presumed 指基于现有信息而“推定/假定”为真，但尚未得到证实。

definition.en: generally believed to be true, even though it is not proven; assumed
definition.zh: 被普遍认为是真的（但未被证明）；推定的；假定的

examples.en: The presumed cause of the fire was faulty wiring.
examples.zh: 这场火灾的推定原因是电线故障。

examples.en: He is the presumed winner, but the final results aren’t out yet.
examples.zh: 他被认为是可能的赢家，但最终结果还没公布。

definition.en: thought to exist or be the case; supposed
definition.zh: 被认为存在或属实的；所谓的

examples.en: They interviewed the presumed eyewitness to the accident.
examples.zh: 他们采访了那位据称目击了事故的人。

extraExplanation: “Presumed”常见于新闻、法律、学术写作，语气比“guessed（猜的）”更正式，表示“基于现有信息的合理推断”，但仍保留不确定性。
常见搭配：presumed innocent（推定无罪）、presumed dead（推定死亡）、presumed cause/reason（推定原因）。其中“presumed innocent”来自法律原则“presumption of innocence（无罪推定）”。

summary.en: “Presuming” usually means “assuming something is true,” and it can also suggest being too bold or overconfident.
summary.zh: “Presuming”常指“假定/想当然”，有时也可表示“冒昧、过于自信”。

definition.en: assuming something is true (often without full proof); taking something for granted
definition.zh: 假定；设想（常指没有充分证据就认为是真的）；想当然

examples.en: Presuming he’s free, we can meet at 6.
examples.zh: 假如他有空，我们可以六点见。

examples.en: You’re presuming a lot without asking her first.
examples.zh: 你没先问她就做了很多想当然的假设。

definition.en: the -ing form of “presume”: to assume; or to behave too boldly (often in a rude or overconfident way)
definition.zh: “presume”的现在分词：假定；或指冒昧、太自以为是（常带无礼/过于自信的含义）

examples.en: I’m presuming that the email is accurate.
examples.zh: 我暂且认为那封邮件的信息是准确的。

examples.en: He was presuming to tell the expert how to do the job.
examples.zh: 他竟然冒昧地教专家怎么干这份工作。

extraExplanation: “Presuming”常用于句首作条件语气，类似“assuming”：Presuming (that) …, …。语气比“assuming”更容易带出“凭什么这么想”的暗示，尤其在批评时。
区分：presume vs. assume。两者都可译为“假设/假定”，但presume更常表示“根据某些迹象推断、或未经证实就认定”，语气有时更武断；assume相对更中性、用于讨论或推理更常见。

summary.en: Presumption means an assumption (often without enough proof), a legal inference treated as true unless disproved, or rude overconfidence/forwardness.
summary.zh: Presumption 可指（1）证据不足的假定/推定，（2）法律上的“推定”（如无罪推定），也可指（3）冒昧、放肆、自以为是的态度。

definition.en: An assumption that something is true, often made without enough proof.
definition.zh: 推定；假定：在证据不足时就认为某事为真。

examples.en: There is a presumption that the missing hikers are safe until proven otherwise.
examples.zh: 在有相反证据之前，一般推定失踪的徒步者是安全的。

examples.en: His presumption that everyone agreed caused confusion in the meeting.
examples.zh: 他想当然地认为大家都同意，导致会议上出现混乱。

definition.en: A legal principle that treats something as true unless it is disproved.
definition.zh: （法律）推定：在被证明相反之前视为成立的原则。

examples.en: In criminal trials, there is a presumption of innocence.
examples.zh: 在刑事审判中，有“无罪推定”原则。

examples.en: The presumption can be challenged with strong evidence.
examples.zh: 这个推定可以用有力证据来推翻。

definition.en: Rude confidence or behavior; acting as if you have a right to do something.
definition.zh: 放肆；冒昧；自以为是：表现得好像自己理所当然有权这么做。

examples.en: It was sheer presumption to walk into the office without an appointment.
examples.zh: 没有预约就走进办公室，真是太冒昧了。

examples.en: I hope you’ll forgive my presumption in offering advice.
examples.zh: 希望你能原谅我的冒昧，我提出了一些建议。

extraExplanation: 词源提示：presumption 来自拉丁语前缀 pre-（在……之前）+ sumere（拿、取），本义有“先拿来当作真的/先行认定”的感觉，所以既可指“缺乏证据的假定”，也可指法律中的“推定”。
常见搭配：a presumption that…（认为……的推定/假定）；presumption of innocence（无罪推定）；on the presumption that…（基于……的假设）。
易混词区分：assumption 更中性、常用于日常“假设”；presumption 常暗示“证据不足却先认定”，或带有“冒昧/放肆”的语气；supposition 更偏“猜测”。

summary.en: Presumptively means “by presumption”—assumed true until proven otherwise; in formal use, it can also mean “probably.”
summary.zh: presumptively 表示“推定地/假定地”——在没有相反证据前先视为真实；在正式语境中也可表示“很可能”。

definition.en: In a way that is assumed to be true based on available evidence, until proven otherwise.
definition.zh: 以“推定/假定”为前提地；根据现有证据先认为是真的，除非被证明不是。

examples.en: The defendant is presumptively innocent until the trial ends.
examples.zh: 在审判结束前，被告推定无罪。

examples.en: Children are presumptively eligible for free meals if their family income is very low.
examples.zh: 如果家庭收入很低，孩子通常会被推定符合免费餐食资格。

definition.en: Probably; likely (used when something is expected, but not 100% certain).
definition.zh: 大概率地；很可能（表示预期如此，但并非百分之百确定）。

examples.en: She will presumptively win the nomination, but anything can happen.
examples.zh: 她很可能会赢得提名，但事情仍可能有变数。

examples.en: The package should presumptively arrive by Friday.
examples.zh: 包裹大概率会在周五前到。

extraExplanation: “presumptively”常见于法律、政策和正式写作，语气比“probably/likely”更正式，强调“在缺乏相反证据之前先这样认定”。
词根提示：presume（推定/假定）+ -tive + -ly。常与“presumptively innocent/eligible/valid”搭配。

summary.en: “Presumptuous” describes someone who is too confident and oversteps boundaries, or an idea that is assumed without proof.
summary.zh: “presumptuous”指人过于自信而越界、冒昧无礼；也可指缺乏证据的想当然判断。

definition.en: Too confident and not showing enough respect; acting as if you have the right to do something when you don’t.
definition.zh: 放肆的；冒昧的；自以为是而不够尊重的（仿佛自己有权这么做，其实并没有）。

examples.en: It was presumptuous of me to give advice before I understood the whole situation.
examples.zh: 在没弄清整个情况前就给建议，是我太冒昧了。

examples.en: He sounded presumptuous, as if he could speak for everyone in the group.
examples.zh: 他说话很放肆，好像他能代表小组里所有人。

examples.en: Sorry if this is presumptuous, but may I ask you a personal question?
examples.zh: 如果这样有点冒昧的话，能否问你一个私人问题？

definition.en: Based on an assumption rather than clear proof; taken for granted.
definition.zh: 基于推测而非明确证据的；想当然的。

examples.en: Their claims were presumptuous and not supported by data.
examples.zh: 他们的说法想当然，而且没有数据支持。

examples.en: It would be presumptuous to say the project will succeed without testing it first.
examples.zh: 在没测试之前就说项目一定会成功，这样想当然了。

extraExplanation: “presumptuous”来自“presume”（擅自认为/推定）。语气通常偏负面，强调越界、唐突或不够谦逊。
常见搭配：presumptuous of sb (to do sth)（某人做某事很冒昧）；a presumptuous remark/assumption（放肆的话/想当然的假设）。
近义词对比：arrogant 更偏“傲慢自大”；rude 更偏“无礼粗鲁”；presumptuous 更强调“越过身份/权限的界限”。

summary.en: “Presuppose” means to assume something in advance or to require it as a necessary condition.
summary.zh: “presuppose”指在事先就预先假定某事为真，或把某事当作必要前提。

definition.en: to assume or accept something as true before it has been proven; to take something for granted
definition.zh: （在未证实前）预先假定；想当然地认为

examples.en: The plan presupposes that everyone has access to the internet.
examples.zh: 这个计划预先假定每个人都能上网。

examples.en: His apology presupposed that he had done something wrong.
examples.zh: 他的道歉想当然地认为他做错了什么。

examples.en: Good communication presupposes trust between people.
examples.zh: 良好的沟通以人们之间的信任为前提。

definition.en: to require something as a necessary condition; to depend on something being true
definition.zh: 以……为前提；要求……作为必要条件

examples.en: The job presupposes a high level of responsibility.
examples.zh: 这份工作要求高度的责任感作为前提。

examples.en: Freedom of choice presupposes that people have real options.
examples.zh: 选择自由以人们拥有真实选项为前提。

extraExplanation: “presuppose”常用于学术写作、新闻评论和正式讨论，语气比“assume”更正式，强调“某个说法/计划背后隐含的前提”。
词源上来自“pre-（在前）+ suppose（假设）”，所以核心感觉是“先假设、先默认一个前提”。在逻辑或语言学里也常说“a presupposition（预设）”。
常见搭配：presuppose that…（预设……）；presuppose something（以……为前提）。近义但有差别：assume（一般的假设）、take for granted（更口语，带“想当然”意味）、imply（暗示，不一定是必要前提）。

summary.en: A presupposition is a background assumption taken for granted, especially in language where certain phrases imply something is already true.
summary.zh: presupposition 指被默认成立的背景前提；在语言中常表现为某些表达暗含“某事已为真”的信息。

definition.en: An assumption or belief that is taken for granted before something is said, argued, or done (often not stated directly).
definition.zh: 预设；预先假定（在说话、论证或行动之前被默认成立的想法，常常不明说）。

examples.en: The question carries the presupposition that you did something wrong.
examples.zh: 这个问题预设了你做错了什么。

examples.en: Her argument rests on the presupposition that money equals happiness.
examples.zh: 她的论点建立在“金钱等于幸福”这一预设上。

examples.en: In everyday conversation, we often make presuppositions without noticing.
examples.zh: 在日常对话中，我们常常在不知不觉中做出预设。

definition.en: In linguistics, information that a speaker assumes is already accepted as true by the listener, and that usually remains true even if the sentence is negated.
definition.zh: （语言学）预设信息：说话者认为听话者已接受为真的信息，而且通常在句子被否定时仍然成立。

examples.en: “She stopped smoking” presupposes that she used to smoke.
examples.zh: “她戒烟了”预设她以前抽烟。

examples.en: Even in “She didn’t stop smoking,” the presupposition that she once smoked often remains.
examples.zh: 即使在“她没有戒烟”中，“她以前抽烟”这个预设通常仍然存在。

extraExplanation: “presupposition”常与“assumption（假设）”对比：assumption更泛，可能只是暂时的推测；presupposition强调被当作背景事实来默认，尤其在提问或表达时会“悄悄带入”。
常见会触发预设的表达（triggers）包括：stop/continue（停止/继续）、again（再次）、too/also（也）、even（甚至）、the/this/that + 名词（特指）、wh-问题（who/when/why等）。例如“Why did you come late?”往往预设“你来晚了”。
学习提示：当你觉得某句话“带节奏”或“默认你同意某点”时，可以问自己：它暗含了什么前提？这有助于更批判地理解广告、新闻标题和面试/辩论问题。

summary.en: “pret” is usually an informal short form of “pretense,” or it can refer to the brand Pret A Manger.
summary.zh: “pret”通常是“pretense（装作/虚饰）”的非正式缩写；也可能指连锁品牌 Pret A Manger。

definition.en: (informal, abbreviation) pretense; a claim or show that is not sincere.
definition.zh: （非正式缩写）pretense 的缩写；虚假的表象或不真诚的装作。

examples.en: He dropped the pret and told the truth.
examples.zh: 他不再装了，说出了真相。

examples.en: Her kindness felt like pret to impress the boss.
examples.zh: 她的好意像是为了讨好老板而装出来的。

definition.en: A brand name: Pret A Manger, a café/sandwich chain (especially in the UK and some other countries).
definition.zh: 品牌名：Pret A Manger（常见于英国等地的咖啡/三明治连锁店）。

examples.en: Let’s grab lunch at Pret near the station.
examples.zh: 我们去车站附近的 Pret 吃个午饭吧。

extraExplanation: 在日常英语里，“pret”本身不是标准常用词；更多见于两种情况：一是把 pretense（装作、虚饰）口语化缩写成 pret（多见于非正式写作/对话），二是作为连锁店 Pret A Manger 的简称“Pret”。如果你是在句子里看到“pret”，我也可以帮你根据上下文判断是哪一种用法。

summary.en: “Pretail” is a very rare/nonstandard verb meaning “to curtail in advance.”
summary.zh: “pretail”是非常罕见/非标准动词，大意为“预先削减、提前缩短”。

definition.en: (Very rare / nonstandard) to reduce, limit, or cut short beforehand; to curtail in advance.
definition.zh: （非常罕见／非标准用法）事先减少、限制或缩短；预先削减。

examples.en: To avoid delays, the manager tried to pretail unnecessary meetings before the busy season.
examples.zh: 为了避免耽误进度，经理在旺季前试图预先削减不必要的会议。

examples.en: Some editors pretail long introductions so readers can reach the main point quickly.
examples.zh: 有些编辑会预先缩短冗长的引言，让读者更快进入重点。

extraExplanation:
“pretail”在现代英语中几乎不用，很多词典也不收录；写作中使用可能会被当作拼写错误。更常见、自然的表达是：
- **curtail**（削减、缩短）
- **reduce**（减少）
- **limit**（限制）
如果你想表达“提前削减”，可以说 **curtail in advance** / **reduce beforehand**。

你可能想查的是拼写相近的常用词：
- **retail**（零售）
- **prevail**（盛行；战胜）
- **pre-tail**（把 *pre-* 和 *tail* 拆开写时可理解为“在尾部之前/预先做尾部处理”，但这通常只在特定技术或临时造词语境出现）。

summary.en: Pretence means a false appearance or act of pretending, or a claim to importance or ability (often insincere).
summary.zh: pretence 指“假象/假装”，也可指（常带贬义的）自命不凡或不真诚的声称。

definition.en: a false show or claim meant to make someone believe something that is not true; pretending
definition.zh: 虚假的表现或声称；假装；装作

examples.en: He kept up the pretence that everything was fine.
examples.zh: 他一直装作一切都很好。

examples.en: Under the pretence of helping, she tried to get private information.
examples.zh: 她以“帮忙”为借口，试图获取隐私信息。

definition.en: a claim to importance or skill, often seen as not sincere or not deserved
definition.zh: （常含贬义）自命不凡的姿态；不真诚或不配的声望/能力宣称

examples.en: He has no pretence to being an expert in finance.
examples.zh: 他根本谈不上是金融专家。

examples.en: She spoke without pretence, in a simple and honest way.
examples.zh: 她说话毫不装腔作势，简单而真诚。

extraExplanation: pretence 是英式拼写；美式更常写作 pretense。两者意思相同。
常见搭配：keep up a pretence（维持假象）；under the pretence of…（以……为借口/幌子）；without pretence（不装腔作势）。
文学中常用来描写“表里不一”的社会礼仪或阶级面具，例如人物在社交场合维持体面假象（a pretence of politeness）但内心另有打算。

summary.en: “Pretend” means to act as if something is true when it isn’t, either for fun (make-believe) or to deceive; it can also describe something imaginary.
summary.zh: “pretend”指“假装/装作”，既可用于玩耍式的“假想”，也可表示带欺骗或装腔作势意味的“冒充”；还可作形容词表示“虚构的”。

definition.en: to behave as if something is true when it is not, often for fun, practice, or imagination
definition.zh: 假装；装作（某事是真的，实际上不是），常用于玩耍、练习或想象

examples.en: Let’s pretend this couch is a pirate ship.
examples.zh: 我们来假装这张沙发是一艘海盗船吧。

examples.en: The kids pretended to be asleep when their parents came in.
examples.zh: 父母进来时，孩子们假装睡着了。

definition.en: to claim (often falsely) that you have a quality, feeling, or status
definition.zh: （常带贬义）自称；冒充；佯称（自己拥有某种品质、感受或身份）

examples.en: He pretended to be an expert, but he couldn’t answer basic questions.
examples.zh: 他假装自己是专家，但连基本问题都回答不上来。

examples.en: She didn’t pretend that everything was fine.
examples.zh: 她没有假装一切都很好。

definition.en: imaginary or make-believe; used especially in children’s play
definition.zh: 想象的；虚构的；（尤指儿童游戏中的）假想的

examples.en: They built a pretend castle out of boxes.
examples.zh: 他们用纸箱搭了一个“假想”的城堡。

extraExplanation: “pretend”既可用于积极、中性的“假想游戏/演练”（pretend play），也可用于带批评意味的“装腔作势/冒充”。语气取决于语境。
常见结构：pretend to do（假装做某事）；pretend (that) + 从句（假装……）；pretend + 名词/身份（假装是……）。
与“play”搭配时很常见：play pretend / pretend play，指儿童通过角色扮演学习社交与语言。

summary.en: “Pretended” is the past form of “pretend”: to act as if something is true, often to hide the truth or for play.
summary.zh: “pretended”是“pretend”的过去式/过去分词：指假装某事为真，常用于掩饰事实或在游戏中扮演想象。

definition.en: to behave as if something is true when it is not; to make a show of (a feeling, condition, or action)
definition.zh: 假装；装作（某事是真的或某种感觉/状态存在，实际上并非如此）

examples.en: He pretended to be asleep when his mom walked in.
examples.zh: 妈妈走进来时，他假装睡着了。

examples.en: I pretended I didn’t hear the joke because it was rude.
examples.zh: 因为那个玩笑很粗鲁，我假装没听见。

definition.en: (often in stories/children’s play) to imagine and act out a role or situation
definition.zh: （常用于故事或儿童游戏）扮演；假想并演出来

examples.en: The kids pretended they were astronauts exploring Mars.
examples.zh: 孩子们假装自己是宇航员在探索火星。

examples.en: Let’s pretend this sofa is a pirate ship.
examples.zh: 我们假装这张沙发是一艘海盗船吧。

definition.en: to claim or say that you have something (especially in a way that seems not true)
definition.zh: 自称；声称（常带有不真实或不可信的含义）

examples.en: He pretended to know the answer, but he was guessing.
examples.zh: 他假装知道答案，其实是在猜。

extraExplanation: “pretended”是动词“pretend”的过去式/过去分词。常见搭配：pretend to + 动词（pretend to be / pretend to know / pretend to sleep）；pretend (that) + 从句（pretend (that) you’re fine）。
语气差别：pretend通常表示“明知不真却装作”，而act像“表演/做出某种样子”，更中性；make believe更偏“（孩子）想象游戏”的感觉。

summary.en: A pretender is someone who falsely claims a right to power or pretends to be something they’re not.
summary.zh: pretender 指（常带贬义的）觊觎权位者，或冒充、假装成某种身份的人。

definition.en: a person who claims (often falsely) to have a right to an important position, title, or power
definition.zh: （常指虚假地）声称自己有权获得重要职位、头衔或统治权的人；觊觎者

examples.en: Several pretenders to the throne appeared after the king died.
examples.zh: 国王去世后，出现了几个王位觊觎者。

examples.en: The general was seen as a pretender who wanted the presidency for himself.
examples.zh: 那位将军被视为觊觎总统职位的人。

definition.en: a person who pretends to be something they are not; a fake
definition.zh: 冒充者；伪装者；假冒的人

examples.en: He turned out to be a pretender who lied about being a doctor.
examples.zh: 他后来被发现是个冒充者，谎称自己是医生。

examples.en: Online, it can be hard to tell real experts from pretenders.
examples.zh: 在网上，很难分辨真正的专家和冒牌货。

extraExplanation: 这个词常见于历史与政治语境，尤其是“pretender to the throne（王位觊觎者）”。例如英国历史上常提到“the Old Pretender / the Young Pretender”，指詹姆斯党（Jacobites）支持的王位继承主张者。
与“contender（竞争者）”不同，pretender 往往带有“名不正言不顺”或“带欺骗成分”的负面含义。

summary.en: Pretenderism is support for (or behavior like) a pretender—most often a political movement backing a disputed claimant to a throne; more broadly, it can mean acting with false authority or identity.
summary.zh: Pretenderism 指支持“觊觎者/自称继承者”的行为或政治运动（常见于王位继承争议）；更广义可指冒充权威或身份、装腔作势的作风。

definition.en: The practice, belief, or political movement of supporting a pretender (a person who claims a title—especially a throne—without generally accepted right).
definition.zh: 拥立“王位/头衔觊觎者”的做法、信念或政治运动（指支持自称有权继承头衔——尤指王位——但其合法性不被普遍承认的人）。

examples.en: After the king’s death, pretenderism split the court into rival factions.
examples.zh: 国王去世后，拥立觊觎者的政治活动使宫廷分裂为对立派系。

examples.en: The novel portrays pretenderism as a dangerous mix of loyalty, rumor, and ambition.
examples.zh: 小说把拥立觊觎者描写成一种由忠诚、流言与野心混合而成的危险力量。

definition.en: In a broader (often critical) sense: the habit or style of acting like a pretender—putting on false importance, authority, or identity.
definition.zh: 更广义（常带贬义）：像“冒牌者”一样行事的习惯或作风——装腔作势、假装权威或身份。

examples.en: Her essay criticizes the pretenderism of influencers who pretend to be experts in everything.
examples.zh: 她的文章批评了一些网红的“装专家”作风，仿佛什么都懂。

examples.en: He dropped the pretenderism and spoke honestly about what he didn’t know.
examples.zh: 他不再装腔作势，而是坦诚地说出自己不知道的地方。

extraExplanation: “pretenderism”由 pretender（觊觎者/自称者）+ -ism（主义/倾向）构成。历史语境里常见于王位继承争议：例如支持某位“王位觊觎者”的群体或运动，可称为一种 pretenderism。
注意它与“pretentiousness（矫饰、装腔作势）”意思接近但不完全相同：pretenderism 更强调“自称/冒充某种身份或权利”的行为或立场，语感更偏政治或身份主张。

summary.en: “Pretending” means acting as if something is true (often in play), or describing something that is fake or not sincere.
summary.zh: “pretending”表示“假装/扮演”（常见于游戏情境），也可形容“不真诚、装出来的”。

definition.en: acting as if something is true when it is not; doing something in an imaginary or playful way (present participle/gerund of “pretend”)
definition.zh: 假装（某事是真的）；（常指游戏中）装作、扮演（“pretend”的现在分词/动名词）

examples.en: She was pretending to be asleep when her mom came in.
examples.zh: 妈妈进来时，她假装在睡觉。

examples.en: The kids are pretending to be astronauts.
examples.zh: 孩子们在扮演宇航员。

examples.en: Pretending can be a fun way to learn through play.
examples.zh: 假扮/角色扮演可以是一种通过游戏学习的有趣方式。

definition.en: not sincere or genuine; fake in a way that tries to seem real
definition.zh: 不真诚的；装出来的；假惺惺的

examples.en: He gave a pretending smile and quickly looked away.
examples.zh: 他挤出一个假笑，随即把目光移开。

examples.en: I’m tired of her pretending kindness.
examples.zh: 我厌倦了她那种装出来的善意。

extraExplanation: “pretending”既可指儿童的“角色扮演/想象游戏”（通常是积极、中性的），也可指成人在社交中“装作/假装”的行为（可能带负面评价）。语境通常决定它是“play pretend（玩扮演）”还是“pretend to…（假装……）”。

summary.en: “Pretends” means “acts as if something is true” (or claims something) when it isn’t.
summary.zh: “pretends”表示“假装某事为真/装作”，也可指“自称、冒充（实际上并非如此）”。

definition.en: (third-person singular of “pretend”) to act as if something is true when it is not, often for fun, politeness, or to deceive.
definition.zh: （pretend 的第三人称单数）假装；装作某事为真（其实不真），常用于玩乐、礼貌或欺骗。

examples.en: He pretends to be asleep when his alarm goes off.
examples.zh: 闹钟响时，他假装在睡觉。

examples.en: She pretends she doesn’t care, but she actually does.
examples.zh: 她装作不在乎，但其实很在乎。

examples.en: The child pretends to be a doctor and checks everyone’s “heartbeat.”
examples.zh: 孩子假装当医生，给大家“听心跳”。

definition.en: to claim or say that you have a quality, ability, or reason when you really do not.
definition.zh: 自称（有某种品质、能力或理由）但实际上没有。

examples.en: He pretends to know everything about the topic.
examples.zh: 他自称对这个话题无所不知。

examples.en: The company pretends to be environmentally friendly, but it pollutes the river.
examples.zh: 那家公司自称环保，但却污染河流。

extraExplanation: “pretend”常见结构：pretend to + 动词（pretend to be / pretend to do），或 pretend (that) + 从句（pretend (that) you’re fine）。口语里 that 常省略。
“pretend”既可以是“扮演/假装（多为玩乐、无害）”，也可以是“装腔作势/冒充（带负面：欺骗、虚伪）”，语境会决定语气。

summary.en: Pretense means a false appearance or excuse used to hide the truth or justify something.
summary.zh: pretense 指用来掩盖真相的“假象/伪装”，也可指为行为辩护的“借口/托词”。

definition.en: A false display or claim meant to hide the truth; an appearance that is not genuine.
definition.zh: 假象；虚饰；（用来掩盖真相的）虚假表现或说法。

examples.en: He dropped the pretense of being calm and started shouting.
examples.zh: 他不再假装冷静，开始大喊大叫。

examples.en: Under the pretense of helping, she tried to get private information.
examples.zh: 她以帮忙为借口，试图获取隐私信息。

examples.en: They met under the pretense of a business lunch.
examples.zh: 他们以商务午餐为幌子见面。

definition.en: A false reason or excuse used to justify an action.
definition.zh: 借口；托词（用来为某个行为找的虚假理由）。

examples.en: He called on the pretense that he needed advice.
examples.zh: 他以需要建议为借口打电话来。

examples.en: Don’t use safety as a pretense to control people.
examples.zh: 不要拿安全当借口去控制别人。

extraExplanation: “pretense / pretence” 两种拼写都对：美式英语更常用 pretense，英式英语更常用 pretence。
常见搭配：drop the pretense（不再伪装）、under the pretense of…（以……为幌子/借口）、on the pretense that…（以……为借口）。
词义上它通常带有负面色彩，暗示“不真诚/欺骗”；如果想表达更中性的“装作/假装”，也可用 pretend（动词）。

summary.en: Pretension means showing off in an unnatural way to seem important, or (more formally) claiming a right or status.
summary.zh: Pretension 指装腔作势、故作高深；也可指（较正式）对某种权利或身份的资格主张。

definition.en: a way of behaving or speaking that shows you think you are more important, intelligent, or cultured than other people
definition.zh: （言行中的）自命不凡；矫饰；装腔作势（表现得比别人更重要、更聪明或更有文化）

examples.en: He spoke with an air of pretension that made others uncomfortable.
examples.zh: 他说话时带着一种装腔作势的劲儿，让别人很不自在。

examples.en: The film tries too hard to be deep, and the result feels like pretension.
examples.zh: 这部电影太想显得深刻，结果反而让人觉得很矫饰。

definition.en: a claim or hope to have something, especially something important or special (often used in formal contexts)
definition.zh: （尤用于正式语境）声称/自称有……的资格；要求；奢望

examples.en: She has no pretension to the throne.
examples.zh: 她并没有继承王位的资格主张。

examples.en: His pretension to expert status was challenged by the committee.
examples.zh: 委员会质疑他自称“专家”的资格。

extraExplanation: “pretension”常带负面评价，强调“装出来的高级/有品位”，而不一定真的具备。对应形容词是“pretentious（装腔作势的）”。
在文学与评论写作中常见：批评作品“more pretension than substance”（华而不实），意思是形式与姿态大于真正内容。
注意与“ambition（抱负）”区分：ambition偏中性/正面，指努力追求目标；pretension更像不相称的自我抬高或不恰当的资格主张。

summary.en: “Pretentious” describes someone or something that tries to appear more impressive or cultured than it really is.
summary.zh: “pretentious”指某人或某事刻意显得更厉害、更有文化或更高级，给人装腔作势、做作的感觉。

definition.en: Trying to seem more important, intelligent, talented, or cultured than is really true; showing off in a way that feels insincere or arrogant.
definition.zh: 装腔作势的；自命不凡的；故作高深（给人不真诚、傲慢的炫耀感）。

examples.en: The restaurant’s menu sounded pretentious, but the food was actually simple and tasty.
examples.zh: 这家餐厅的菜单听起来很装，但食物其实很朴实也很好吃。

examples.en: He uses big words to sound smart, which can come across as pretentious.
examples.zh: 他用很多大词想显得聪明，这可能会让人觉得很装。

examples.en: Some people find modern art pretentious, while others genuinely enjoy it.
examples.zh: 有些人觉得现代艺术很装腔作势，但也有人真心喜欢。

extraExplanation: “pretentious”常带负面评价，重点不是“有品味/高级”，而是“刻意表现得比实际更高级或更懂”，让人觉得在炫耀或不真诚。
搭配很常见：pretentious language（装腔的措辞）、pretentious attitude（摆架子）、pretentious film/art（故作高深的电影/艺术）。
语气强弱：pretentious（偏直接批评）≈ showy/affected（做作）/snobby（势利、看不起人）；想更委婉可说 a bit self-important（有点自以为是）或 trying too hard（用力过猛）。

summary.en: Preternatural describes something unusually beyond normal nature—often eerily extraordinary, sometimes suggesting the supernatural without fully claiming it.
summary.zh: preternatural 用来形容“超出自然常态、异乎寻常”的事物，常带一点诡异或超自然的感觉，但不一定明确说真的超自然。

definition.en: Beyond what is normal or natural; strange in a way that feels supernatural (but not necessarily truly magical).
definition.zh: 超出常态或自然的；怪异得像“超自然”（但不一定真的有魔法或神力）。

examples.en: She had a preternatural calm during the emergency.
examples.zh: 在紧急情况中，她表现出一种超乎寻常的冷静。

examples.en: He could hear footsteps with preternatural sharpness.
examples.zh: 他的听觉敏锐得异乎寻常，连脚步声都听得很清楚。

definition.en: Relating to things that are outside the ordinary course of nature; not explained by known natural laws (often used in older or religious writing).
definition.zh: 指超出自然常规、难以用已知自然规律解释的（常见于较旧或宗教语境）。

examples.en: The story describes preternatural events that the villagers feared.
examples.zh: 故事描写了村民们害怕的那些超自然般事件。

examples.en: In older texts, preternatural signs were sometimes read as warnings.
examples.zh: 在较旧的文本中，“超自然征兆”有时被解读为警示。

extraExplanation: “preternatural”常让人联想到“supernatural（超自然）”，但语气更微妙：它可以只是“异常、非同寻常到像超自然”，不一定明确宣称真的有鬼神或魔法。
词源上来自拉丁语：praeter-（在……之外）+ naturalis（自然的）。因此字面意思就是“在自然之外”。
常见搭配：preternatural calm（异常冷静）、preternatural strength（异乎寻常的力量）、preternatural silence（诡异的寂静）、preternatural ability（非同一般的能力）。在文学里常用来营造不安或神秘氛围。

summary.en: A pretest checks your starting level before teaching or a main exam; it can also mean giving that test.
summary.zh: pretest 指在教学或正式考试前用来测起点水平的“预测验”，也可作动词表示“进行预测验”。

definition.en: A test given before instruction or before a main test to measure a person’s starting level or baseline knowledge.
definition.zh: 在教学或正式测验之前进行的测试，用来衡量学习者的起点水平或基础知识。

examples.en: We took a pretest on grammar before the course started.
examples.zh: 课程开始前，我们先做了一份语法预测验。

examples.en: The teacher used the pretest results to decide what to review.
examples.zh: 老师根据预测验结果决定要复习哪些内容。

definition.en: To give someone a test before instruction or before the main assessment.
definition.zh: 在教学或正式评量之前对某人进行预先测验。

examples.en: Researchers pretested participants to make sure the two groups started at the same level.
examples.zh: 研究人员先对参与者进行预测验，以确保两组起点水平相同。

extraExplanation: “pre-”表示“在……之前”。因此 pretest 常用于教育与研究中，用来建立“基线（baseline）”，方便和之后的 post-test（后测）对比学习效果。
写作中也常见作形容词用法：pretest score（预测验分数）、pretest questionnaire（预测问卷）。

summary.en: A pretext is a made-up reason used to hide the real motive.
summary.zh: pretext 指用来掩盖真实动机的虚假理由或借口。

definition.en: a false or invented reason used to hide the real reason for doing something
definition.zh: （常指虚假的）借口；托词，用来掩盖真实动机

examples.en: He used a work meeting as a pretext to leave early.
examples.zh: 他以要开工作会议为借口，提前离开了。

examples.en: The inspection was just a pretext to intimidate the community.
examples.zh: 这次检查只是用来恐吓社区的借口。

definition.en: to use something as a false reason or excuse (often followed by “that”)
definition.zh: 以……为借口；托词（常接 that 从句）

examples.en: They pretexted that they needed more time to finish the report.
examples.zh: 他们托词说需要更多时间完成报告。

extraExplanation: “pretext”通常带有“表面理由不真实、真正动机另有其因”的暗示，比一般的“excuse（理由/借口）”更偏负面、更强调掩饰性。
词源上可理解为“织在前面的东西”，引申为“摆在前面用来遮掩的理由”。

summary.en: “Pretexts” are false reasons given to hide the real motive; it’s the plural of “pretext.”
summary.zh: “pretexts”是“pretext”的复数，指为掩盖真实动机而编造的借口/托词。

definition.en: (plural of pretext) A false or invented reason used to hide the real reason for doing something.
definition.zh: （pretext 的复数）借口；托词：用来掩盖真实动机的（往往是编造的）理由。

examples.en: He used work deadlines as pretexts to avoid family gatherings.
examples.zh: 他用工作截止日期当借口，来躲开家庭聚会。

examples.en: The inspection was a pretext for searching the office.
examples.zh: 这次检查只是为了搜查办公室的托词。

definition.en: (as a verb) To use something as a false reason to justify an action; to pretend a reason.
definition.zh: （作动词）以……为借口；托词：用表面理由来掩饰真实原因。

examples.en: They pretexted safety concerns to cancel the event.
examples.zh: 他们以安全问题为借口取消了活动。

examples.en: She pretexted a headache and left early.
examples.zh: 她托词头疼，提前离开了。

extraExplanation: “pretext”比“excuse”更强调“表面理由不真实、用来掩盖真实目的”。“excuse”可以是真实原因也可以是借口。
常见搭配：on the pretext of + 名词/动名词（以……为借口）。例如：He entered on the pretext of delivering a package（他以送包裹为借口进入）。
语体上：名词“pretext”较常见；动词“to pretext”相对书面、少见，日常更常说“use … as a pretext / claim … as an excuse”。

summary.en: Pretiare is a rare Latin-derived verb meaning “to value/appraise; to set a price on.”
summary.zh: Pretiare 是一个罕见的拉丁语来源动词，意为“评估价值/估价；定价”。

definition.en: (Rare; from Latin) to value, appraise, or set a price on something.
definition.zh: （罕见；源自拉丁语）给……估价、评定价值或定价。

examples.en: In a few scholarly texts, writers use pretiare to mean “to appraise” an object’s worth.
examples.zh: 在少数学术文本中，作者用 pretiare 表示“评估”物品的价值。

examples.en: The accountant was asked to pretiare the company’s assets before the sale.
examples.zh: 在出售前，会计被要求对公司的资产进行估价。

extraExplanation: pretiare 不是现代英语里的常用词，更常见于拉丁语语境或引用拉丁语的学术写作中。现代英语通常用 value / appraise / price 来表达同样意思。
词源来自拉丁语 pretiare（与 pretium“价格、价值”同源）。因此它常带有“估价、定价”的书面色彩。

summary.en: Pretiosus is a Latin adjective meaning “precious, valuable, costly,” mostly seen in scientific names.
summary.zh: pretiosus 是拉丁语形容词，意为“珍贵的、有价值的、昂贵的”，在英语中多见于学名等场景。

definition.en: (Latin; used in English mainly in scientific names) “precious; valuable; costly.”
definition.zh: （拉丁语；在英语中多见于学名等）“珍贵的；有价值的；昂贵的。”

examples.en: In taxonomy, the epithet pretiosus often suggests the organism was considered valuable or noteworthy.
examples.zh: 在生物分类学中，种加词 pretiosus 往往暗示该生物被认为“珍贵”或“值得关注”。

examples.en: The catalogue lists the specimen as “pretiosus,” meaning “precious.”
examples.zh: 目录把该标本标为“pretiosus”，意思是“珍贵的”。

extraExplanation: pretiosus 来自拉丁语 pretiosus，源头是 pretium（“价格、价值”）。因此它带有“有价、值钱”的语感，常用于文学拉丁语或作为生物学命名（学名）中的形容词性种加词。
在学名里，pretiosus 不是英语日常词汇；日常英语更常用 precious（珍贵的）或 valuable（有价值的）。

summary.en: Pretium is a Latin loanword meaning “price” or “value,” used mostly in mottos or formal/classical contexts.
summary.zh: Pretium 是拉丁语借词，意为“价格/价值”，多用于格言或较正式、古典的语境。

definition.en: (Rare in modern English) A Latin word meaning “price,” “value,” or “worth,” sometimes used in mottos, academic writing, or specialized contexts.
definition.zh: （现代英语中较少单独使用）拉丁语词，意为“价格、价值、值得之处”，有时出现在格言、学术写作或特定领域语境中。

examples.en: The inscription uses the Latin word pretium to mean “value” rather than “money.”
examples.zh: 这段铭文用拉丁语 pretium 表达“价值”，而不是“钱”。

examples.en: Some writers borrow pretium to give the sentence a classical tone.
examples.zh: 有些作者借用 pretium 来让句子带有古典气息。

extraExplanation: pretium 本质上是拉丁语名词，在英语里通常不会像普通词汇那样日常使用，更常见于引文、格言、校训或带有“古典/学术”风格的表达中。
它常被拿来对比英语的 price / value：pretium 更偏“价值/代价”的抽象含义，具体要看上下文。
如果你是在某个短语里看到它（例如某些格言或学术标题），把整句话贴出来会更容易准确解释其含义与语气。

summary.en: Pretoria is South Africa’s administrative capital and a major government city, now within the City of Tshwane.
summary.zh: 比勒陀利亚是南非的行政首都和重要政府城市，现属于茨瓦内（Tshwane）大都会。

definition.en: The administrative (executive) capital city of South Africa, located in the northern part of the country; now part of the metropolitan city of Tshwane.
definition.zh: 比勒陀利亚：南非的行政（政府执行机构）首都，位于该国北部；现属茨瓦内（Tshwane）大都会的一部分。

examples.en: Many foreign embassies in South Africa are based in Pretoria.
examples.zh: 南非的许多外国大使馆设在比勒陀利亚。

examples.en: She moved from Johannesburg to Pretoria for a government job.
examples.zh: 她为了政府工作从约翰内斯堡搬到比勒陀利亚。

extraExplanation: “Pretoria”常被称为南非的“行政首都”，而开普敦（Cape Town）是立法首都，布隆方丹（Bloemfontein）是司法首都——这是南非历史与政治结构形成的结果。
比勒陀利亚在官方语境中也常与“茨瓦内（Tshwane）”并列出现：Tshwane是大都会名称，而Pretoria常指中心城区与传统名称。

summary.en: “Prettier” usually means “more pretty/attractive,” and it can also refer to the code-formatting tool named Prettier.
summary.zh: “prettier”通常表示“更漂亮/更好看”，也可以指名为 Prettier 的代码格式化工具。

definition.en: Comparative form of “pretty”: more attractive, pleasant, or nice to look at.
definition.zh: “pretty”的比较级：更漂亮的、更好看的、更讨人喜欢的。

examples.en: This dress is prettier than the one I wore yesterday.
examples.zh: 这条裙子比我昨天穿的那条更漂亮。

examples.en: The park looks prettier in spring when the flowers bloom.
examples.zh: 春天花开的时候，公园看起来更美。

examples.en: She drew a prettier picture after practicing for a week.
examples.zh: 练习了一周后，她画出了一幅更好看的画。

definition.en: (Proper noun) “Prettier”: a popular tool that automatically formats code to a consistent style.
definition.zh: （专有名词）Prettier：一种常用的代码格式化工具，会自动把代码排版成统一风格。

examples.en: Our team uses Prettier to keep the code style consistent.
examples.zh: 我们团队用 Prettier 来保持代码风格一致。

examples.en: Run Prettier before you open a pull request.
examples.zh: 在你提交拉取请求之前先运行一下 Prettier。

extraExplanation: “prettier”在口语里也常用来表示“更好/更合适”，不一定只指外貌，比如：That’s a prettier solution（那是个更好的解决办法）。
作为比较级，“prettier”的拼写规则是：pretty 结尾的 -y 变成 -i，再加 -er（pretty → prettier）。

summary.en: “Prettiest” means “the most pretty/attractive,” the superlative form of “pretty.”
summary.zh: “prettiest”表示“最漂亮的/最好看的”，是“pretty”的最高级。

definition.en: Superlative form of “pretty”: the most pretty; the most attractive or pleasant to look at.
definition.zh: “pretty”的最高级：最漂亮的；最好看的。

examples.en: She wore her prettiest dress to the party.
examples.zh: 她穿上自己最漂亮的裙子去参加派对。

examples.en: This is the prettiest garden in the neighborhood.
examples.zh: 这是附近最漂亮的花园。

examples.en: He chose the prettiest photo for his profile.
examples.zh: 他选了最好看的照片当头像。

extraExplanation: “prettiest”是规则变化：pretty → prettier → prettiest。注意拼写变化：以辅音字母+y结尾时，y变成i再加-est。
“pretty”既可以表示“漂亮/好看”，也可以表示“相当、挺”（副词，如 pretty good=挺不错）。但“prettiest”通常只用作形容词最高级，表示外表或视觉上的“最漂亮”。
语感上，“pretty/prettiest”常用于较轻松、日常的称赞；形容风景、衣服、照片、花园等都很自然。正式场合也可用更中性的词，如 “most beautiful”。

summary.en: Prettily means “in a pretty/pleasing way,” and less commonly “fairly/quite” as an adverb of degree.
summary.zh: prettily 常指“漂亮地/优雅地”，较少见地也可表示程度“相当/挺”。

definition.en: In a pretty or attractive way; in a pleasing, graceful manner.
definition.zh: 以漂亮或迷人的方式；令人愉悦、优雅地。

examples.en: She was dressed prettily for the party.
examples.zh: 她为聚会打扮得很漂亮。

examples.en: The garden was prettily decorated with lights.
examples.zh: 花园用灯饰布置得很漂亮。

definition.en: To a small or moderate degree; fairly, quite (often used before an adjective).
definition.zh: 相当、挺（常放在形容词前，表示程度不算极端）。

examples.en: It’s prettily clear what happened.
examples.zh: 发生了什么其实挺清楚的。

examples.en: I’m prettily sure he’ll come on time.
examples.zh: 我相当确定他会准时来。

extraExplanation: “prettily”来自形容词“pretty”（漂亮的/相当的）加副词后缀“-ly”。口语中更常用“pretty + 形容词”（如“pretty sure/pretty good”）；“prettily”表示程度时较少见，听起来更书面或更强调语气。

summary.en: Prettiness means the quality of being pretty or having a decorative, charming look—sometimes suggesting it’s only surface-level.
summary.zh: Prettiness 指“漂亮/美丽的特质”，也可指“装饰性、讨喜的外观”，有时带“只停留在表面”的意味。

definition.en: the quality of being pretty; pleasant or attractive in appearance (often in a gentle or delicate way)
definition.zh: 漂亮；美丽（通常指柔和、精致的美感）

examples.en: The room had a simple prettiness, with white flowers on the table.
examples.zh: 房间有一种朴素的美，桌上摆着白色花朵。

examples.en: Her dress was chosen for comfort, not just prettiness.
examples.zh: 她选这条裙子是为了舒适，不只是为了好看。

examples.en: Some people confuse prettiness with deeper beauty.
examples.zh: 有些人会把“漂亮”与更深层的“美”混为一谈。

definition.en: a decorative, cute, or charming look or style (sometimes implying it is superficial)
definition.zh: （装饰性的）可爱/讨喜的外表或风格（有时暗示比较表面、缺乏深度）

examples.en: The film has visual prettiness, but the story is weak.
examples.zh: 这部电影画面很漂亮，但故事很薄弱。

examples.en: He was tired of the restaurant’s prettiness and wanted something more authentic.
examples.zh: 他厌倦了那家餐厅的“精致好看”，想要更真实的感觉。

extraExplanation: “prettiness”常带有“精致、甜美、柔和”的感觉；和“beauty”相比，语气更轻，有时也会被用来暗示“只有表面好看”。在评论艺术、电影或设计时，prettiness 可能是褒义（很美），也可能是轻微贬义（太追求好看、缺少内容）。
搭配很常见：simple prettiness（朴素的美）、mere prettiness（仅仅的漂亮）、surface prettiness（表面美观）。

summary.en: “Pretty” most commonly means “attractive” (adj.) and can also mean “fairly/quite” (adv.).
summary.zh: pretty最常见意思是“漂亮的”（形容词），也常用作副词表示“相当、挺”。

definition.en: attractive in a delicate or pleasant way; nice to look at (often about people, faces, small things, or scenes)
definition.zh: 漂亮的；好看的（多指外表清秀、赏心悦目，也常用于人、脸、小物件或景色）

examples.en: She has a pretty smile.
examples.zh: 她的笑容很甜美。

examples.en: That’s a pretty little house.
examples.zh: 那是一栋很精致漂亮的小房子。

examples.en: The garden looks pretty in spring.
examples.zh: 花园在春天看起来很美。

definition.en: fairly; quite; to a noticeable degree (used to make an adjective or adverb stronger)
definition.zh: 相当；挺；颇（用于加强语气，表示程度不低）

examples.en: I’m pretty tired after work.
examples.zh: 我下班后挺累的。

examples.en: It’s pretty cold outside today.
examples.zh: 今天外面相当冷。

definition.en: to make (something) look attractive, neat, or decorative
definition.zh: 装饰；美化（使某物更好看、更整洁）

examples.en: They prettied up the room for the party.
examples.zh: 他们把房间布置得更漂亮来办派对。

extraExplanation: “pretty”作形容词时，语气通常比“beautiful”更轻、更日常，常带有“清秀、可爱、精致”的感觉；“beautiful”更正式、力度更强，常用于强调出众的美。
“pretty”作副词表示“相当、挺”，语气一般比“very”弱一点，但比“a little”强：pretty good（挺不错）、pretty sure（相当确定）。注意：在正式写作中可用“quite/fairly/rather”替换以显得更正式。
口语里“pretty + 负面形容词”很常见：pretty bad/pretty hard，表示“程度不轻”。

summary.en: “Prev” usually means “previous” in navigation; less commonly it can mean “preview” in informal notes.
summary.zh: “Prev”通常表示“previous（上一个/上一页）”；较少情况下在非正式备注里也可能指“preview（预览）”。

definition.en: an abbreviation of “previous”; commonly used in buttons, menus, or notes to mean the item before the current one
definition.zh: “previous（之前的/上一个）”的缩写；常见于按钮、菜单或笔记中，表示当前项之前的那个

examples.en: Click “Prev” to go back to the previous page.
examples.zh: 点击“Prev”返回上一页。

examples.en: See the prev chapter for more details.
examples.zh: 更多细节请看上一章。

definition.en: an informal abbreviation of “preview,” especially in file names or production notes (less common than “preview” or “previews”)
definition.zh: “preview（预览/预告）”的非正式缩写，常见于文件名或制作备注中（不如直接写 preview 常见）

examples.en: Upload the prev before publishing the final video.
examples.zh: 发布最终视频前先上传一个预览版。

examples.en: The folder contains image prev files.
examples.zh: 这个文件夹里有图片预览文件。

extraExplanation: “Prev/Next”是英语界面里非常固定的搭配：Prev = previous（上一个/上一页），Next = next（下一个/下一页）。在正式写作中一般不要用“prev”，而是写全“previous”。
不同领域里“prev”可能有其他缩写含义（例如技术文档或内部代号），理解时优先结合上下文：如果出现在导航按钮上，几乎一定是“previous”。

summary.en: Prevail means to win against difficulty, to be common or dominant, or (formally) to persuade someone to do something.
summary.zh: Prevail 常指在困难或对抗中获胜、某事物普遍盛行/占优势，或（较正式）劝服某人去做某事。

definition.en: to win or be more successful than others, especially after a competition or conflict
definition.zh: （尤指在竞争或冲突后）获胜；战胜

examples.en: Despite early mistakes, our team prevailed in the final minutes.
examples.zh: 尽管一开始失误不断，我们的队还是在最后几分钟赢了。

examples.en: Justice will prevail in the end.
examples.zh: 正义终将获胜。

definition.en: to be widespread or common in a particular place or time
definition.zh: （在某地或某时期）盛行；普遍存在

examples.en: A sense of fear prevailed throughout the city.
examples.zh: 整座城市弥漫着恐惧感。

examples.en: In those days, handwritten letters still prevailed over emails.
examples.zh: 那时候，手写信仍比电子邮件更常见。

definition.en: to persuade someone to do something (often used with “upon/on” in formal English)
definition.zh: （较正式）说服；劝服（常与 upon/on 连用）

examples.en: Her friends prevailed upon her to stay a little longer.
examples.zh: 朋友们劝她再多待一会儿。

extraExplanation: “Prevail”常出现在比较正式或书面语中，尤其在新闻、演讲、文学里：如“truth/justice will prevail”（真理/正义终将获胜）。它强调经历阻力后仍然“占上风”。
固定搭配：prevail over（战胜/胜过）；prevail upon/on sb to do sth（说服某人做某事）；prevailing adj. 表示“流行的；占优势的”，如 prevailing opinion（主流观点）、prevailing winds（盛行风）。

summary.en: “Prevailed” means “won/triumphed,” “was widespread,” or “persuaded (on/upon).”
summary.zh: “prevailed”可表示“获胜/占上风”“普遍存在/盛行”，也可表示“说服（on/upon）”。

definition.en: Past tense/past participle of “prevail”: to win or be more successful than someone or something else.
definition.zh: “prevail”的过去式/过去分词：战胜；胜过；占上风。

examples.en: In the end, their team prevailed and won the championship.
examples.zh: 最终，他们的队伍占了上风，赢得了冠军。

examples.en: Science prevailed over rumor during the public health crisis.
examples.zh: 在公共卫生危机中，科学战胜了谣言。

definition.en: To be common or widespread in a place or time.
definition.zh: （在某地或某时期）流行；普遍存在。

examples.en: A sense of optimism prevailed after the peace talks.
examples.zh: 和平谈判后，乐观情绪普遍存在。

examples.en: Silence prevailed in the room when the news was announced.
examples.zh: 消息宣布时，房间里一片寂静。

definition.en: To persuade someone to do something (often used with “on/upon”).
definition.zh: （常与 on/upon 连用）说服某人做某事。

examples.en: She prevailed upon him to stay a little longer.
examples.zh: 她说服他再多待一会儿。

extraExplanation: “Prevail”常见搭配：prevail over（战胜/胜过）；prevail upon/on someone to do something（说服某人做某事）；在“情绪/状态 + prevailed”结构里，表示“（某种氛围）笼罩/占据”，如：Calm prevailed（平静占据一切）。
词源上来自拉丁语 praevalere，含义是“更强、更有力量”，因此既能表示“赢了”，也能表示“（某种情况）占主导、普遍存在”。

summary.en: Prevailing means “most common/dominant” and sometimes “winning.”
summary.zh: Prevailing 常指“普遍/主流/占主导”，也可指“获胜的”。

definition.en: Most common or widespread at a particular time; generally accepted or dominant.
definition.zh: 在某一时期最常见或最普遍的；普遍被接受的；占主导的。

examples.en: The prevailing opinion is that the plan will cost too much.
examples.zh: 普遍的看法是这个计划会花费太多。

examples.en: In many places, the prevailing culture values group harmony.
examples.zh: 在许多地方，主流文化重视群体和谐。

definition.en: Winning or being successful (often in a contest, debate, or legal case).
definition.zh: 获胜的；占上风的（常用于比赛、辩论或诉讼中）。

examples.en: The prevailing team advanced to the finals.
examples.zh: 获胜的队伍晋级决赛。

examples.en: She was the prevailing party in the lawsuit.
examples.zh: 她是诉讼中的胜诉方。

extraExplanation: “Prevailing”来自动词“prevail”（取胜、占优势、盛行）。在新闻和学术写作里很常见，用来描述“主流观点/趋势/态度”（prevailing view/trend/attitude）。
常见搭配：prevailing winds（盛行风）、prevailing wisdom（主流看法/普遍认知）、prevailing rates（现行费率/市场利率）。其中“prevailing winds”是地理与气象的固定表达。

summary.en: “Prevailingly” means “mostly; in a generally predominant way,” and it is formal and less common in everyday English.
summary.zh: “Prevailingly”意为“总体上、主要地（占主导地）”，较正式，日常英语中不算常用。

definition.en: In a prevailing or predominant way; generally or for the most part.
definition.zh: 以占优势的方式；普遍地；大体上。

examples.en: The neighborhood is prevailingly residential, with only a few shops.
examples.zh: 这个社区总体上以住宅为主，只有少量商店。

examples.en: The article is prevailingly critical, though it includes some praise.
examples.zh: 这篇文章总体上偏批评，尽管也有一些称赞。

extraExplanation: “Prevailingly”比较少见、略显正式，日常写作里更常用“mostly / mainly / generally / predominantly”。它通常用来概括“整体趋势/主要特征”，语气比“mostly”更书面、更强调“占主导”。
词源上来自“prevail”（占上风、盛行、普遍存在）+ 副词后缀“-ly”。常见搭配有：prevailingly + adj.（如 prevailingly negative/positive/urban）。

summary.en: “Prevails” means “wins/succeeds” or “is most common/accepted,” depending on context.
summary.zh: “Prevails”可表示“获胜/成功”，也可表示“盛行/普遍存在”，具体看语境。

definition.en: to win or be successful, especially after a difficult situation or competition
definition.zh: （尤指经历困难或竞争后）获胜；成功；占上风

examples.en: After a long legal battle, she finally prevailed in court.
examples.zh: 经过漫长的法律诉讼，她最终在法庭上胜诉。

examples.en: In the end, patience and teamwork prevailed over panic.
examples.zh: 最终，耐心和团队合作战胜了恐慌。

definition.en: to be the most common or widespread; to exist or be accepted in a particular place or time
definition.zh: （观念、风俗、情况等）盛行；普遍存在；占主导

examples.en: A sense of optimism prevails in the city these days.
examples.zh: 最近这座城市里弥漫着乐观的气氛。

examples.en: In many cultures, respect for elders still prevails.
examples.zh: 在许多文化中，尊敬长辈仍然很普遍。

extraExplanation: “prevails”是动词“prevail”的第三人称单数现在时：He/She/It prevails。
常见搭配：prevail over + 对手/困难（战胜）；prevail on/upon + 人（说服，较正式用法）；the prevailing view/weather（盛行的观点/主要的天气）。
文学与正式语体中常见：“truth prevails”（真理终将胜利）这类表达带有价值判断与格言色彩。

summary.en: Prevalence means how common or widespread something is; in health research, it often means the percentage of people with a condition.
summary.zh: Prevalence 指某事物的普遍/流行程度；在医学研究中常指某种疾病或状况的“患病率”（人群所占比例）。

definition.en: The fact or condition of being common, widespread, or existing in many places or among many people.
definition.zh: 普遍性；流行程度；广泛存在的状态。

examples.en: The prevalence of smartphones has changed how people communicate.
examples.zh: 智能手机的普及改变了人们的沟通方式。

examples.en: Researchers studied the prevalence of allergies in children.
examples.zh: 研究人员调查了儿童过敏的患病率（流行程度）。

definition.en: In public health and research: the proportion of a population that has a particular condition at a specific time (or over a period).
definition.zh: （公共卫生/研究）患病率：在某一时间点（或一段时期内）人群中具有某种疾病或状况的比例。

examples.en: The report estimated the prevalence of diabetes at 11% among adults.
examples.zh: 报告估计成年人糖尿病患病率为11%。

examples.en: Point prevalence measures how many people have the condition on a given day.
examples.zh: 时点患病率衡量在某一天有该状况的人有多少。

extraExplanation: 词源提示：prevalence 来自 prevail（占优势、盛行）。因此它常用于描述“某事很常见/很普遍”的程度。
写作搭配：the prevalence of + 名词（如 the prevalence of misinformation）。常与 increase/rise, high/low, measure/estimate 等词连用。
易混词：prevalence（患病率/普遍程度）≠ incidence（发病率：一段时间内“新发生”的病例数或比例）。

summary.en: “Prevalent” means common and widespread.
summary.zh: prevalent 表示“普遍的、广泛存在的、常见的”。

definition.en: Common and widespread; happening or existing in many places or among many people.
definition.zh: 普遍的；广泛存在的；常见的。

examples.en: Smartphones are prevalent in many countries.
examples.zh: 智能手机在许多国家很普遍。

examples.en: In winter, colds and flu are prevalent at schools.
examples.zh: 冬天在学校里感冒和流感很常见。

examples.en: This belief is prevalent among young adults.
examples.zh: 这种观念在年轻人中很普遍。

extraExplanation: 词源提示：pre- 表示“在前/预先”，-valent 与“力量、影响”有关。prevalent 原义有“占优势的、流行的”之意，现在最常用来表达“普遍存在、很常见”。
常见搭配：prevalent in（在……中普遍存在）；most prevalent（最常见的）；become/grow more prevalent（变得更普遍）。

summary.en: Prevalent means common and widespread, often used in formal contexts; it can also suggest a problem is widespread.
summary.zh: Prevalent 表示“普遍的、广泛存在的”，较正式；也常用来形容问题“泛滥、到处都是”。

definition.en: Common and widespread; happening or existing in many places or among many people.
definition.zh: 普遍的；广泛存在的；流行的。

examples.en: Smartphones are prevalent in everyday life.
examples.zh: 智能手机在日常生活中非常普遍。

examples.en: The prevalent opinion was that the plan needed more time.
examples.zh: 普遍的看法是这个计划需要更多时间。

definition.en: (Especially of something negative) widespread and difficult to avoid or control.
definition.zh: （尤指负面事物）泛滥的；常见且难以避免或控制的。

examples.en: Misinformation is prevalent on social media.
examples.zh: 社交媒体上谣言/错误信息很泛滥。

examples.en: In the novel, corruption is portrayed as prevalent in the city.
examples.zh: 在小说中，腐败被描写为在这座城市里非常普遍。

extraExplanation: “prevalent”比“common”更正式，常用于新闻、学术或报告语境，强调“分布范围广”。
搭配很常见：prevalent + in/among（在……中普遍存在），例如：prevalent in society / prevalent among teenagers。
词源上来自拉丁语“praevalere”（占优势、胜过），所以它也带有“占主导地位”的感觉。

summary.en: “Prevaleo” isn’t a standard English word; it likely means “prevail”: to win, to be widespread, or to persuade (prevail on/upon).
summary.zh: “prevaleo” 不是标准英语词，通常是想写 “prevail”：指获胜、盛行，或（prevail on/upon）说服某人。

definition.en: (Likely intended: “prevail”) to win or succeed after a struggle; to be stronger than opposing forces.
definition.zh: （你可能想写：prevail）在斗争后获胜；战胜对立力量。

examples.en: Justice will prevail in the end.
examples.zh: 正义最终会获胜。

examples.en: Our team prevailed after a difficult second half.
examples.zh: 在艰难的下半场之后，我们队还是赢了。

definition.en: (Likely intended: “prevail”) to be the most common or widespread in a place or time.
definition.zh: （你可能想写：prevail）在某地或某时期最常见；盛行。

examples.en: A friendly atmosphere prevails in the office.
examples.zh: 办公室里弥漫着友好的氛围。

examples.en: In many coastal areas, strong winds prevail in winter.
examples.zh: 在许多沿海地区，冬季常刮大风。

definition.en: (Likely intended: “prevail”) to persuade someone; to influence someone to do something (often used with “on/upon”).
definition.zh: （你可能想写：prevail）说服某人；促使某人做某事（常与 on/upon 连用）。

examples.en: I finally prevailed on him to see a doctor.
examples.zh: 我终于说服他去看医生。

examples.en: She prevailed upon her parents to let her study abroad.
examples.zh: 她说服父母让她出国留学。

extraExplanation: “prevaleo” 不是常见英语单词，最可能是把 **prevail** 拼错了（常见误拼：prevale/prevail）。
词根上，**prevail** 来自拉丁语 *prae-*（在前）+ *valere*（强壮、有力量），核心感觉是“更强、更占优势”。
相关词：**prevalent**（adj. 普遍的、流行的），如：*Smoking is prevalent among young adults.*（吸烟在年轻人中很普遍。）

summary.en: Prevaricate means to avoid the truth or a clear answer by being vague or misleading.
summary.zh: prevaricate 指用含糊或误导的话来回避真相或明确回答。

definition.en: to avoid telling the truth or giving a clear answer, especially by speaking in a vague or misleading way
definition.zh: （尤指用含糊或误导的话）搪塞、支吾其词，以回避说真话或给出明确答复

examples.en: When the reporter asked about the missing money, the official prevaricated.
examples.zh: 当记者问到失踪的资金时，那位官员开始支吾其词。

examples.en: Stop prevaricating and tell me what really happened.
examples.zh: 别再搪塞了，告诉我到底发生了什么。

definition.en: to delay or avoid making a decision by using excuses or indirect talk
definition.zh: （用借口或拐弯抹角的话）拖延、回避作出决定

examples.en: We can’t keep prevaricating; we need to choose a plan today.
examples.zh: 我们不能一直拖着不决；今天必须选定一个方案。

extraExplanation: “prevaricate”常用于正式语境（新闻、法庭、政治、商业沟通），语气偏负面，暗示对方不坦诚或故意闪躲。
词源上与拉丁语中“偏离正道/歪向一边”的意思有关，因此它常带有“离开事实、绕开问题”的感觉。
易混词：lie（说谎，直接给出不实信息） vs. prevaricate（不一定直接说假话，但故意含糊、转移话题、不正面回答）。
常见搭配：prevaricate about/over sth（对某事含糊其辞）；prevaricate when asked（被问到时支吾）。

summary.en: “Prevent” means to stop something from happening or to keep someone from doing something.
summary.zh: “prevent”表示“阻止某事发生”或“阻止某人做某事/使其无法做”。

definition.en: to stop something from happening; to keep something from occurring
definition.zh: 预防；阻止（某事发生）

examples.en: Wearing a seat belt can prevent serious injuries.
examples.zh: 系安全带可以预防严重受伤。

examples.en: Regular handwashing helps prevent the spread of germs.
examples.zh: 经常洗手有助于防止细菌传播。

definition.en: to keep someone from doing something; to stop someone from taking an action
definition.zh: 阻止（某人做某事）；使（某人）无法做某事

examples.en: Heavy snow prevented us from driving to work.
examples.zh: 大雪使我们无法开车去上班。

examples.en: Nothing could prevent her from trying again.
examples.zh: 没有什么能阻止她再试一次。

extraExplanation: 常见搭配：prevent + 名词（prevent accidents / prevent disease）；prevent + 人 + from + 动词-ing（prevent someone from leaving）。口语和书面语都很常用。
语气区别：prevent 强调“事先或过程中把事情挡住”；stop 更偏“让正在发生的事停下来”；avoid 强调“自己绕开、尽量不去做/不碰到”。

summary.en: Preventable describes something negative that could be stopped or avoided by taking action beforehand.
summary.zh: preventable 用来形容通过事先采取措施就能阻止或避免的（多为不良后果）。

definition.en: able to be stopped or avoided before it happens.
definition.zh: 可预防的；可避免的（指事情发生前能被阻止或避免）。

examples.en: Many deaths from heart disease are preventable with healthy habits and regular checkups.
examples.zh: 许多心脏病导致的死亡是可预防的，只要保持健康习惯并定期体检。

examples.en: This accident was preventable if the safety rules had been followed.
examples.zh: 如果遵守安全规定，这起事故本来是可以避免的。

extraExplanation: “preventable”通常修饰不好的结果（如疾病、事故、错误、损失），强调“事前采取措施就能避免”。常见搭配有：preventable disease（可预防疾病）、preventable injury（可避免伤害）、highly preventable（高度可预防）。
注意与“avoidable”对比：两者都可译为“可避免的”，但preventable更强调通过预防措施（规则、疫苗、教育、检查）来阻止；avoidable更偏“本可以不这样”的一般性选择或判断。

summary.en: “Preventably” means “in a way that could have been prevented; avoidably.” It’s a formal adverb often used in health, safety, and policy contexts.
summary.zh: “Preventably”意为“以本可以预防/避免的方式；可避免地”。它是较正式的副词，常用于健康、安全与政策等语境。

definition.en: In a way that could have been prevented; avoidably.
definition.zh: 以本可以预防（避免）的方式；可避免地。

examples.en: The accident was preventably caused by speeding.
examples.zh: 这起事故是由于超速而本可以避免地发生的。

examples.en: She fell ill from a preventably unsafe food choice.
examples.zh: 她因选择了本可避免的不安全食物而生病。

examples.en: Many deaths are preventably linked to a lack of basic medical care.
examples.zh: 许多死亡本可以避免，却与缺乏基本医疗护理有关。

extraExplanation: “Preventably”来自形容词“preventable（可预防的）”，加上副词后缀“-ly”。在日常英语里更常见的表达是“could have been prevented（本可以避免）”或“was avoidable（是可避免的）”；“preventably”偏正式、常见于新闻、学术或公共卫生语境（如“preventable deaths / preventably caused injuries”）。
注意语气：说某事“preventably”发生，往往暗含“有人本应采取措施却没有”，因此在沟通中可能带有批评或追责意味。

summary.en: Preventative means intended to prevent something bad from happening (same meaning as preventive).
summary.zh: preventative 意为“预防性的”，用于表示旨在防止不好的事情发生（与 preventive 同义）。

definition.en: (Especially in health and safety) intended to stop something bad from happening; preventive.
definition.zh: （尤指健康与安全领域）旨在防止不好的事情发生的；预防性的。

examples.en: Regular handwashing is a simple preventative measure against many infections.
examples.zh: 经常洗手是预防多种感染的简单措施。

examples.en: The company introduced preventative maintenance to reduce breakdowns.
examples.zh: 公司引入预防性维护来减少故障。

extraExplanation: “preventative”和“preventive”意思相同；在现代英语里两者都常见，但在一些专业写作（尤其医学、学术与技术文档）中，“preventive”更常被视为更标准、更简洁的拼写。日常交流中用“preventative”也完全可以。

summary.en: “Prevented” means something was stopped from happening or someone was kept from doing something (past form of “prevent”).
summary.zh: “Prevented”表示“阻止/防止”，是 prevent 的过去式或过去分词。

definition.en: (past tense/past participle of prevent) Stopped something from happening, or kept someone from doing something.
definition.zh: （prevent 的过去式/过去分词）阻止某事发生；阻止某人做某事。

examples.en: The heavy rain prevented the game from starting on time.
examples.zh: 大雨使比赛无法准时开始。

examples.en: Her injury prevented her from running in the race.
examples.zh: 她的伤让她无法参加比赛跑步。

examples.en: Quick action prevented a small problem from becoming a crisis.
examples.zh: 迅速的行动阻止了小问题演变成危机。

definition.en: Stopped or reduced damage, danger, or an unwanted situation (often with illnesses, accidents, or conflict).
definition.zh: （常用于疾病、事故或冲突）预防或避免（伤害、危险或不良情况）。

examples.en: Wearing a seat belt prevented serious injury.
examples.zh: 系安全带避免了严重受伤。

examples.en: Vaccines have prevented many diseases from spreading widely.
examples.zh: 疫苗已阻止许多疾病大范围传播。

extraExplanation: “prevented”常用于两种结构：1) prevent + 名词：The fence prevented accidents.（围栏防止事故。）2) prevent + 人/物 + from + 动词-ing：They prevented him from leaving.（他们阻止他离开。）在口语中 from 有时会被省略，但正式写作中通常保留。
语法上，“prevented”也可作过去分词用于被动语态或完成时：The fire was prevented. / They have prevented further damage.

summary.en: “Prevent” means to stop something from happening or to stop someone from doing something.
summary.zh: “prevent”表示阻止某事发生，或阻止某人做某事。

definition.en: to stop something from happening, or make it impossible or less likely
definition.zh: 阻止（某事发生）；预防；防止（变得不可能或不太可能）

examples.en: Wearing a seat belt can prevent serious injuries.
examples.zh: 系安全带可以防止严重受伤。

examples.en: The new rules are meant to prevent accidents at work.
examples.zh: 新规定旨在预防工作中的事故。

definition.en: to stop someone from doing something
definition.zh: 阻止某人做某事

examples.en: The rain prevented us from going out.
examples.zh: 下雨阻止了我们出门。

examples.en: Nothing can prevent her from trying again.
examples.zh: 没有什么能阻止她再试一次。

extraExplanation: “preventen”不是常见英语单词，通常是把“prevent”拼错了。正确拼写：prevent。
常见搭配：prevent + noun（prevent disease 预防疾病）；prevent + someone + from + -ing（prevent him from leaving 阻止他离开）。注意：美式英语中“prevent someone doing…”较少见，学习时优先用“prevent someone from doing…”。

summary.en: Preventing means stopping something from happening or taking action to avoid a problem before it starts.
summary.zh: Preventing 指阻止某事发生，或采取行动在问题出现前加以预防。

definition.en: stopping something from happening; making it impossible for something to happen
definition.zh: 阻止某事发生；使某事不可能发生

examples.en: Wearing a seat belt helps in preventing serious injuries.
examples.zh: 系安全带有助于防止严重受伤。

examples.en: The new rules are aimed at preventing cheating.
examples.zh: 新规定旨在防止作弊。

definition.en: used to describe an action, rule, or measure that stops a problem or illness before it starts (often before a noun)
definition.zh: （作定语）指“预防性的；防止……的”，常放在名词前修饰措施或行为

examples.en: Preventing measures include washing your hands and getting enough sleep.
examples.zh: 预防措施包括洗手和保证充足睡眠。

examples.en: They held a workshop on preventing cyberbullying.
examples.zh: 他们举办了一个关于预防网络霸凌的讲座。

extraExplanation:
“preventing”是动词“prevent”的 -ing 形式：
1）进行时：They are preventing further damage.（他们正在防止进一步的损害。）
2）动名词：Preventing mistakes saves time.（避免错误能节省时间。）
3）介词后常用动名词：help in preventing / focus on preventing。

summary.en: Prevention means taking action to stop a problem before it happens.
summary.zh: Prevention 指在问题发生之前采取行动来避免它发生。

definition.en: the act of stopping something bad or unwanted from happening
definition.zh: 预防；防止（坏事或不想要的事情发生的行为）

examples.en: Handwashing is an easy form of disease prevention.
examples.zh: 洗手是一种简单的疾病预防方式。

examples.en: The program focuses on crime prevention in the neighborhood.
examples.zh: 这个项目专注于社区的犯罪预防。

examples.en: Prevention is better than cure.
examples.zh: 预防胜于治疗。

extraExplanation: 词源提示：prevention 来自拉丁语前缀 pre-（“在……之前”）+ 动词 prevent（“阻止”）。核心意思是“在问题发生之前就把它挡住”。
常见搭配：disease prevention（疾病预防）、accident prevention（事故预防）、crime prevention（犯罪预防）、prevention measures（预防措施）、prevention program（预防项目）。
语体与用法：prevention 常用于公共卫生、医学、政策与安全领域，语气正式、书面一些；日常口语里也会说 prevent + 名词（例如 prevent accidents）。

summary.en: Preventive means meant to stop problems before they happen, and it can also refer to a preventive measure or medicine.
summary.zh: preventive 表示“预防性的”，也可作名词指“预防措施/预防药”。

definition.en: Intended to stop something bad from happening; used for prevention.
definition.zh: 预防性的；旨在阻止不好的事情发生的。

examples.en: Regular exercise is a preventive measure against heart disease.
examples.zh: 规律运动是预防心脏病的措施。

examples.en: The dentist recommended preventive care like cleanings every six months.
examples.zh: 牙医建议做预防性护理，比如每六个月洗牙一次。

examples.en: They took preventive steps to avoid data loss by backing up files daily.
examples.zh: 他们采取预防措施，通过每天备份文件来避免数据丢失。

definition.en: A preventive action or medicine taken to avoid illness or harm.
definition.zh: 预防措施；预防药（为避免疾病或伤害而采取的行动或使用的药物）。

examples.en: In some regions, people take a preventive before traveling to areas with malaria.
examples.zh: 在一些地区，人们去疟疾流行区旅行前会服用预防药。

examples.en: Wearing a helmet is a simple preventive for cyclists.
examples.zh: 戴头盔对骑行者来说是一种简单的预防措施。

extraExplanation: “preventive”常见于医疗、公共卫生和风险管理语境（如 preventive care 预防性护理、preventive medicine 预防医学、preventive measure 预防措施）。在英式英语中也常见拼写“preventative”，意思相同；美式英语里“preventive”更常用、更正式。
词源上来自 prevent（预防、阻止）+ -ive（构成形容词，表示“具有……作用/倾向”）。

summary.en: “prevents” means “stops something from happening” (he/she/it prevents).
summary.zh: “prevents”表示“阻止/防止（某事发生）”，是prevent的第三人称单数形式。

definition.en: (third-person singular) to stop something from happening; to keep someone/something from doing something.
definition.zh: （第三人称单数）阻止某事发生；防止；使某人/某物无法做某事。

examples.en: Wearing a seat belt prevents serious injuries in many accidents.
examples.zh: 系安全带可以在许多事故中防止严重受伤。

examples.en: Good planning prevents problems later.
examples.zh: 良好的计划能防止以后出现问题。

examples.en: This rule prevents students from using phones in class.
examples.zh: 这条规定防止学生在课堂上使用手机。

extraExplanation: “prevents”是动词“prevent”的第三人称单数形式（he/she/it prevents）。常见结构：prevent + 名词（prevent accidents）；prevent + 人 + from + doing（prevent someone from doing something）。口语中from有时会被省略，但正式写作里建议保留。

summary.en: Preview means seeing or showing something before its official release—like a movie screening, a trailer, or checking a document before printing.
summary.zh: Preview 指在正式发布前先看/先体验：如电影试映或预告，以及打印前预览文件等。

definition.en: A chance to see or experience something before it is officially available or released.
definition.zh: 在正式发布或公开之前，先行观看或体验某事物的机会。

examples.en: We got a preview of the new movie before it opened in theaters.
examples.zh: 我们在电影正式上映前先看到了新片的预告/试映。

examples.en: The app offers a preview of premium features for seven days.
examples.zh: 这款应用提供七天的高级功能试用预览。

definition.en: To look at or show something in advance, especially to check it or build interest.
definition.zh: （在事先）预览；预先查看或展示（尤指为检查或引起兴趣）。

examples.en: You can preview the document before you print it.
examples.zh: 你可以在打印前预览这份文件。

examples.en: The teacher previewed the next chapter to help students prepare.
examples.zh: 老师先带大家预习了下一章，帮助学生做好准备。

definition.en: Shown or happening before the official release (used before a noun).
definition.zh: 预先的；预览的；先行的（作定语）。

examples.en: There will be a preview screening on Friday night.
examples.zh: 周五晚上会有一场提前试映。

extraExplanation: “preview”常见于媒体与软件场景：电影的“preview”可指“预告片（trailer）”或“试映（preview screening）”；在电脑里“Print Preview”指“打印预览”。具体含义通常要看上下文。
词源上“pre-”表示“在……之前”，加上“view（看）”，字面意思就是“提前看”。
